Guide to the Sylvester Manor Archive 1649-1996

Sylvester Manor Archive

Contents

Record Group I: Sylvester, Brinley, and Lloyd Families

Scope and Contents

Record Group I includes Sylvester, Brinley and Lloyd family items dating from 1649 to 1786. These documents provide evidence of an early northern provisioning plantation actively involved in the Atlantic trades and employing African slave labor, Native Americans, and early European settlers. Financial and accounting evidence of trading activities as well as a number of wills and land ownership documents of various family members provide detailed inventories of possessions during this period.

Series A: Sylvester Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group I, Series A: Sylvester Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from deeds of property sales, enfranchisements, grants, indentures, inventories, and wills, to bills, bonds and receipts, to letters, notation, and genealogical research. This series also includes the earliest evidence of African American slavery on Shelter Island in the form of Grissell (Grizzell) Sylvester's last will and testament, dated 1685. These papers lightly refer to Shelter Island manorial business but also include accounts and ledgers of merchant activities in Boston while the settlement identified as part of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.

This series is dominated by sales and settlement papers concerning Horse Neck, a property on the northern shore of Long Island. Horse Neck was purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester for his daughter Grissell (Grizzell) (1654-1691), who was engaged to be married to Latimer Sampson, who died before they were wed. Grissell then married Boston merchant James Lloyd, who appears in this series as well as in Series C: Lloyd Family. Following a dispute over the ownership of the Horse Neck property purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester and given to Latimer Sampson, it was determined that Sampson's will entitled the property to Grissell and therefore, Lloyd.

The name "Horse Neck" was originally used by Huntington farmers who grazed horses there in the 17th century. Matinecock Native Americans sold Horse Neck (or Caumsett, "place by sharp rock") to English settlers from Oyster Bay in 1654 before Boston merchant James Lloyd acquired the property in 1676. On March 8, 1685, Lieutenant Governor Thomas Dongan granted James Lloyd the royal patent for Horse Neck, formally renaming it the "Manor of Queens Village," annexed to Oyster Bay, Queens County. James Lloyd remained in Boston, renting the property out to tenant farmers, but in 1711 his 24-year-old son, Henry, gave up a shipping business in Newport, Rhode Island, to farm the Manor. His "salt box" home, the Henry Lloyd Manor House, stills survives on the grounds of Caumsett State Historic Park, where it has been restored, maintained, and interpreted by the Lloyd Harbor Historical Society.

What was once referred to as Horse Neck is now called Lloyd Neck, and is part of Lloyd Harbor, a village in Suffolk County, while the Incorporated Village of Lloyd Harbor is located in the town of Huntington, Long Island, New York. The Papers of the Lloyd Family of the Manor of Queens Village, Lloyd Neck, Long Island, New York in book (1654-1826) and manuscript form (1654-1822) are preserved at the New York Historical Society.

These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These items are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Biographical Note

The Sylvester Family was involved in the original purchase of Shelter Island in 1651 for the purposes of establishing a provisioning plantation for its Barbados sugar operations. Nathaniel Sylvester (1610 - 1680) was a member of an English merchant family that had briefly relocated to the Netherlands before moving to Barbados to manage the family's interests in a sugar plantation. He married Grissell (Grizzell) Brinley (1635 - 1687), who was the daughter of Francis Brinley, a merchant of some wealth based in Boston and Rhode Island. The couple came to live on Shelter Island in 1652 as the first Europeans to permanently settle there. The couple produced eleven children, including Giles (Gyles) Sylvester (1657 - 1704), who inherited the heart of the estate from his father, while portions were given to the four other sons (portions of the island had also been given to Constant Sylvester). The Sylvesters were sympathetic to the Quaker religion, and provided shelter to several of its followers during persecutions in other areas of New England. After Nathaniel's death, the property was no longer affiliated with the sugar plantation in Barbados that had been operated by Nathaniel's brother Constant. Giles (Gyles) Sylvester died without heir and following a legal dispute, the property passed to Brinley Sylvester (1694 - 1752), Giles' nephew via his brother Nathaniel II. Brinley Sylvester pursued trading and other maritime merchant activities. He married Mary Burrough and had two daughters, of which Mary Sylvester would marry Thomas Dering and later inherit the estate.

Professional Correspondence

Dates:
1649 April 14 & 16
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Seal

Addressed To: John Winthrop

Sent From: Lion Gardiner

In Reference To: Business; Hay, Food, English lamb

2 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 6.5" x 8"

Lion Gardiner (1599 – 1663), an early English settler and soldier in the New World, founded the first English settlement in what became the state of New York on Long Island. His legacy includes Gardiners Island, which is held by his descendants. John Winthrop (January 12, 1587 - March 26, 1649) was a wealthy English Puritan lawyer and one of the leading figures in the founding of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, the first major settlement in what is now New England after Plymouth Colony. The Winthrop Family Papers are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society.

Legal Record with Notation

Dates:
1654 September 20; 1658 May 14
Scope and Contents

1 Deed of Property Sale

Acquistion: Horse Neck, [Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY]

Grantee: Nathaniel Sylvester

Grantor: Wyandanch (Wyandance)

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional / Real Estate; [Includes Signatures of Witnesses]

4 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 7.25" x 11.25"

Wyandanch (Wyandance) (born circa 1620 in Montauk, Long Island - died 1660) was a sachem of the Montaukett tribe in the mid-17th century on eastern Long Island. He was an influential "alliance chief," a sachem who was responsible for maintaining friendly relations between his tribe and the settlers.

Legal Records with Notation

Dates:
1644 May 6, August 2, October 3; 1655 April 8 & May 6
Scope and Contents

2 Deeds of Property Sale

Acquisition: Horse Neck, [Huntington Bay / Oyster Bay, Long Island, NY]

Buyer: John Leveritt: Captain John Richbell of Oyster Bay

Sales Party: Captain John Scott of Ashford, Long Island [with Macon Cornwall]; John Leveritt of Boston, [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional / Real Estate; [Certified by Robert Howard of Massachusetts Colony with three unidentified signatures]; "Entered & Recorded in the office of New York by Matthew Nicolls, Secretary" ; [Witnesses Richard Nicolls & Robert Howard with one unidentified signature]

2 Parchment Pages; Mounted on Tissue

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 22" x 8.75"

Captain John Scott of Long Island (1634-1696) was a royal advisor, military leader, spy, cartographer, attorney, land speculator, and early settler and leader of Long Island. He lobbied to make Long Island the 14th English colony in North America with himself as governor and, when not appointed by the crown, was elected President of Long Island by that region's leaders.

1669 April 23, November 3; 1670 July 6; 1683 June 16

Addressed To: James Johnson & Peter Oliver of Boston, [Massachusetts Bay Colony]

Sent From: Samuel Bellingham of Amsterdam, [Possibly New Amsterdam Settlement or Capital City of the Netherlands]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Religion; Reverend Higginson, Pastor of the Church of Salem; Handwritten Copy by Nathaniel Oliver [Sylvester]; Receipts from Elizabeth Stone of Hartford, [CT] with witnesses John Higginson, John Hull, Thomas Hinkley

3 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.25" x 12"

Legal Record with Notation

Dates:
1675 March 1
Scope and Contents

1 Last Will & Testament

Estate: Latimer Sampson of Shelter Island

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional; Confirmation Document by Edmund Andros, Esq., "Governor of his Royal Highness James Duke of York & Albany Territories in America," [Leaves his entire estate to Grizzell Sylvester, eldest daughter of Nathaniel Sylvester]; "Past the Office, Matthias Nicolls, Secretary," Court of Sessions East Riding, Southampton

3 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 7.75" x 12.25"

Sir Edmund Andros (December 6, 1637 – February 24, 1714) was an English colonial administrator in North America. He was the governor of the Dominion of New England during most of its three-year existence. Andros served as governor of the provinces of New York, East and West Jersey, Virginia, and Maryland. Before his service in North America, he served as bailiff of Guernsey. Andros' tenure in New England was authoritarian and turbulent, as his views were decidedly pro-Anglican, a negative quality in a region home to many Puritans. His actions in New England resulted in his overthrow during the 1689 Boston revolt. Records documenting Andros' professional life are preserved at the New York Historical Society and the National Archives in Surrey, England.

1 Receipt

Acquisition: Legal Work

Buyer: Brinley Sylvester

In Reference To: Business / Professional; Brinley Sylvester vs. William Nicoll

3 Pages, Bound by String

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 4"

Series B: Brinley Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group I, Series B: Brinley Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from affidavits, deeds of property sales, indentures, inventories, memorandums, and wills, to bills, receipts, and statements of account, to letters, notation, and genealogical research. While this series lightly refers to family conversations about estate settlements, financial transition, and marriage, it is dominated by property management dealings in Rhode Island and records documenting trade in Boston, MA from Francis Brinley, the eldest son of Thomas Brinley, brother of Nathaniel Sylvester's wife Grissell (Grizzell). This series' provenance is unique within the Sylvester Manor Archive as it is largely a research series, full of records purchased by Andrew Fiske and added for relevance. These records are marked with [Fiske Purchase] to indicate this difference. See Record Group V: Fiske Family, Series A: Correspondence and Research for documentation of Fiske's genealogical work behind these purchases.

These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Biographical Note

The Brinley Family Papers are preserved at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Special Collections and University Archives in the W.E.B. Du Bois Library, in which the following biographical and historical content is provided:

Englishmen and colonial Americans, Loyalists and Patriots, colonial Canadians and American citizens, the members of the Brinley family were a diverse group of characters, ranging from auditors to officers, businessmen, lawyers, legislators, book-collectors, historians, aristocratic ladies and housewives, devoted mothers, husbands, and fathers. A few were slave-holders. Yet through decades of tumultuous social and political change, the family maintained certain distinctive traits and traditions, clinging most notably to their strong ties to England and to the status quo at home. The Brinleys were wealthy, business-minded members of the colonial elite, profoundly Protestant, and most were highly educated and steeped in knowledge. Many became prominent public figures and many more served their respective nations in uniform.

The roots of the Brinley family extend back to England, where the common ancestor of the North American branch of the family, Thomas Brinley (1591 - 1661), served as Auditor of the Revenue for James I and Charles I. Thomas' daughter Grissell (Grizzell) was married to Nathaniel Sylvester. When Thomas' eldest son Francis (1626 - 1719) emigrated to Newport, Rhode Island in the mid-seventeenth century, the family's wealth and prestige were transplanted with him. This series documents Francis' professional life as a merchant.

Controlaccess

Series C: Lloyd Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group I, Series C: Lloyd Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from deeds of property sales and memorandums, to bills and bonds, to letters, notation, and research. While this series lightly refers to Horse Neck [Lloyd Neck] and Shelter Island estate settlements, or family conversations about financial transition and marriage, this series is dominated by professional correspondence documenting statements of account and transactions in Boston, MA, Newport, RI and New York, NY.

These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Biographical Note

Horse Neck was purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester for his daughter Grissell (Grizzell) (1654-1691), who was engaged to be married to Latimer Sampson, who died before they were wed. Grissell then married Boston merchant James Lloyd (d. 1698), who appears in this series as well as Series A: Sylvester Family. Following a dispute over the ownership of the Horse Neck property purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester and given to Latimer Sampson, it was determined that Sampson's will entitled the property to Grissell and therefore, Lloyd.

The name "Horse Neck" was originally used by Huntington farmers who grazed horses there in the 17th century. Matinecock Native Americans sold Horse Neck (or Caumsett, "place by sharp rock") to English settlers from Oyster Bay in 1654 before James Lloyd acquired the property in 1676. On March 8, 1685, Lieutenant Governor Thomas Dongan granted James Lloyd the royal patent for Horse Neck, formally renaming it the "Manor of Queens Village," annexed to Oyster Bay, Queens County. James Lloyd remained in Boston, renting the property out to tenant farmers, but in 1711 his 24-year-old son, Henry, gave up a shipping business in Newport, Rhode Island, to farm the Manor. His "salt box" home, the Henry Lloyd Manor House, stills survives on the grounds of Caumsett State Historic Park, where it has been restored, and is maintained and interpreted by the Lloyd Harbor Historical Society.

Horse Neck is now called Lloyd Neck, and is part of Lloyd Harbor, a village in Suffolk County, while the Incorporated Village of Lloyd Harbor is located in the town of Huntington, Long Island, NY. The Papers of the Lloyd Family of the Manor of Queens Village, Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY in book form (1654-1826) and manuscript form (1654-1822) are preserved at the New York Historical Society.

Controlaccess

Dates:
1678 September 26 - 29, October 16
Scope and Contents

1 Indenture with 3 Receipts

Acquisition: "Articles of Agreement for Dividing and Valuation of Horse Neck & Other Lands in Oyster Bay [Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY]"

Grantee: James Lloyd of Boston, [MA]

Grantor[s]: John Bowne of [Flushing] & Robert Storey of New York, Attorneys to Thomas Hart of London, [England]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional / Real Estate; C. Lewis Morris with John [Bradenham], London Merchant; Date of Copy Unknown, circa 18th century, dates of original content are September 26, 27, 29 & October 16, 1678; John Ware bill of exchange; S.V. Cortlandt, Mayor; Thomas Cooper with Edward Shipping of Boston, [MA]; Samuel Wilson for 4 barrels of pork; [Witnesses to Indenture, Articles of Agreement][Captain] Nathaniel Sylvester, William Frampton

4 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.25" x 12.5"

John Bowne (1627 – 1695) was an English immigrant residing in the Dutch colony of New Netherland, who is honored today as a pioneer in the American struggle for religious liberty. With his wife Hannah Feake (1637 - 1678), great-niece of Governor John Winthrop of Massachusetts, they relocated to Flushing, Long Island in 1661 to practice Quakerism. John Bowne's journal and related papers are preserved at the New York Historical Society.

2 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 8.25" x 12.5"

Professional Correspondence

Dates:
1705 April 16
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: Barrett [Dyre] & Henry Lloyd

Sent From: Isaac Norris of Philadelphia, [PA]

In Reference To: Business / Legal; Veal, Wine Sale

2 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 6" x 7.5"

Isaac Norris (July 21, 1671 – June 4, 1735) was a merchant and prominent figure in provincial Pennsylvania, including mayor of Philadelphia in 1724. In 1694 he married Mary, daughter of Thomas Lloyd, president of the council. Their son, Isaac, succeeded his father in business and also became active in politics, serving as speaker of the Assembly. Norris was a slave trader and owner. He and Mary Lloyd freed many of the slaves during their lifetimes or in their wills. Their children, including Elizabeth and Isaac Norris, Jr., freed the rest of them. The Papers of Isaac Norris (1742-1860) are preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

Measurements: 7" x 8"

Personal Correspondence

Dates:
1726 April 4

Sent From: Brinley Sylvester of Shelter Island [Suffolk County, Long Island, NY] [Uncle of Henry Lloyd]

In Reference To: Family; March 29th

2 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 6.5" x 8"

Record Group II: L'Hommedieu Family

Scope and Content note

Record Group II: L'Hommedieu Family contains records belonging to Benjamin L'Hommedieu II, but is made up primarily of the personal and business papers of Ezra L'Hommedieu, a prominent New York attorney and statesman of the Revolutionary Era. They include correspondence, legal and accounting records of both personal and professional nature, U.S. and New York State government records, reports and printed materials, published materials, and papers relating to the settling of lands in Central and Northern New York State. In addition, a collection of papers of Ezra's wife, Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu are included, as are a significant volume of correspondence from two of the executors of his estate, Thomas Lester and Thomas Dering, all of which relate to the maintenance and settlement of the estate and upstate New York lands.

Series A: Benjamin L'Hommedieu II

Scope and Contents

Record Group II, Series A pertains to the professional life of Benjamin L'Hommedieu in that it includes financial and legal records in the form of bills, bonds, indentures, receipts, professional correspondence, and statements of account.

Biographical Note

Benjamin L'Hommedieu II (1694-1755) was the eldest son of Benjamin L'Hommedieu and Patience Sylvester and a grandson of Nathaniel and Grissell Sylvester. Benjamin L'Hommedieu II was a merchant residing in Southold, Long Island. His wed his first wife Mary Conklin in 1713, who later died in 1730. He then married a second time to Martha Bourn (also spelled Bourne in some records) from Sandwich, Massachusetts in 1731.

Series B: Ezra L'Hommedieu

Scope and Contents

Record Group II, Series B pertains to the professional life of Ezra L'Hommedieu in the form of legal records and professional correspondence. Series B includes letters from a number of notable figures in local, state, and national politics, including: George Clinton, Nicoll and William Floyd, David Gelston, General John Smith, Benjamin Tallmadge, Philip Schuyler van Rensselaer, and one letter from Thomas Jefferson.

Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.

Biographical Note

Although never owner of Sylvester Manor, Ezra L'Hommedieu (1734 - 1811) was a person of considerable prominence in the history of Long Island and New York State. L'Hommedieu was educated at Yale College and graduated in 1754, after which he began his legal practice in Southold, Long Island. The L'Hommedieu family was forced to relocate to Middletown, CT during the occupation of Long Island by British forces during the American Revolution, and again during the blockade in the War of 1812. L'Hommedieu was married twice, first to Charity Floyd in 1765, and after Charity Floyd's death in 1785, to Mary Catherine Havens in 1803. Ezra and Mary Catherine had one daughter, Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu. Ezra L'Hommedieu was a Patriot, and began public service in 1775 with his election to the Provincial Congress. L'Hommedieu's list of national, state and local political positions is extensive: delegate to the Provincial Congress 1775-1777; member of the New York State Assembly 1777-1783; member of the Continental Congress from 1779-1783 and 1788; member of the New York State Senate from 1784-1792 and again from 1794-1809; member of the state constitutional convention in 1801; Suffolk County Clerk from 1784 to March 1810 and from March 1811 until his death; and Regent of the University of the State of New York 1787-1811. L'Hommedieu was also granted land patents to extensive holdings in the area of the Twenty Townships, a large tract of land purchased from the Oneida Native Americans in 1788 in what is now Central New York. L'Hommedieu also held lands near Plattsburg, NY and Sandwich, MA, the latter stemming from the Bourn family's property. These items document the surveying, sale and leasing of these lands.

Series C: Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu

Scope and Contents

Record Group II, Series C includes personal correspondence primarily among relatives and close family friends of Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu. In addition, Series C includes Ezra L'Hommedieu estate management records, legal documents, and financial papers.

Biographical Note

Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu was born to Nicoll Havens and Sarah Fosdick of Shelter Island, NY on September 25, 1765. Mary Catherine wed Ezra L'Hommedieu of Southold, Long Island, NY on June 15, 1803. This was Ezra L'Hommedieu's second marriage and they produced one daughter, Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu, born in 1806. Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu's sister Esther Sarah married Sylvester Dering, the son of Thomas Dering, also of Shelter Island. Ezra L'Hommedieu left his estate, which included Sylvester Manor, to Mary Catherine Havens when he passed away on September 27, 1811, and it was later inherited by their daughter Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner and her husband Samuel Smith Gardiner. Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu passed away in 1843.

Series D: Sylvester Dering

Scope and Contents

Record Group II, Series D includes legal, personal, and professional correspondence in past possession of Sylvester Dering, but pertaining to the manangement of Ezra L'Hommedieu's estate.

Biographical Note

Sylvester Dering was born in 1758 to Boston politician Thomas Dering (circa 1716 - 1785) and daughter of Brinley Sylvester, Mary Sylvester. During his lifetime, Sylvester Dering owned and managed Sylvester Manor, in addition to earning the rank of General during the American Revolutionary War. Dering was a brigadier in the Rhode Island state militia and saw action at the Battle of Oriskany in central NY. Sylvester Dering was also a member of the State Assembly for Suffolk County from 1803 - 1804, and became the first vice-president of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society in 1818. Sylvester Dering married Esther Sarah Havens, sister to Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu, wife of Ezra L'Hommedieu; he was appointed as one of the executors of Ezra L'Hommedieu's estate and passed away in 1820. The Dering Family Papers (1755 - 1896) are housed at the William L. Clements Library of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, MI.

Biographical Note

Southold, Long Island, NY attorney and politian Thomas Lester was appointed in Ezra L'Hommedieu's will as one of the executors of his estate.

Record Group III: Gardiner Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group III: Gardiner Family preserves the personal and professional life of Samuel Smith Gardiner and his wife Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner. Series A: Samuel Smith Gardiner includes genres that range from accounting records, correspondence, political and religious manuscripts, to professional legal papers that document Gardiner's law practices in Suffolk County and larger New York. Series B: Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner features personal correspondence and juvenilia.

Biographical and Historical Note

The Gardiners of Shelter Island were descendents of Lion Gardiner, an early English settler and soldier in the New World. In 1639, Lion Gardiner purchased property from the Montaukett Native Americans after his support of the tribe during the Pequot War. With a grant from Charles I, Gardiner procured what became the first colonial English settlement in present-day New York state. What would become Gardiners Island in East Hampton, Suffolk County, was originally in its own jurisdiction affiliated with neither New York nor New England. In 1648, a royal British charter recognized the island as a wholly contained colony, independent of both New York and Connecticut. It was not until the American Revolution was the property declared under New York and East Hampton authority. Gardiners Island has been privately owned for over three hundred years by Lion Gardiner's descendants, and is the only real estate still intact as part of an original royal grant from the English Crown. This record group features the life and work of Samuel Smith Gardiner and his wife Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner.

Series A: Samuel Smith Gardiner

Scope and Contents

Record Group III, Series A pertains to Samuel Smith Gardiner's personal and professional life in which it includes correspondence, financial records, legal papers, and printed materials in the form of government and political circulars, newspapers, and religious manuscripts. In addition, Record Group III, Series A includes David Gardiner professional papers.

Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special Collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.

Biographical Note

Son of Captain Abraham Gardiner (1763 - 1796) and Phebe Dayton, Samuel Smith Gardiner (1789 - 1859) was a member of the prominent and wealthy Gardiner family, who traced their ancestry to early settler Lion Gardiner. Samuel Smith Gardiner was educated at Williams College in Massachusetts, managed the Shelter Island estate, and practiced law in Suffolk County and larger New York. Gardiner was one of the secretaries of the NY State Constitutional Convention of 1821, and a member of the NY State Legislature from 1823-1824. Gardiner wed Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu on August 7, 1823. Debt forced the Dering Family to place the Sylvester Manor estate at auction and Samuel Smith Gardiner purchased the manor house and 578 acres for $10,400. Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner's three daughters Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner, Phoebe Dayton Gardiner, and Frances Eliza Gardiner would later inherit Samuel's estate. After Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner passed away on January 28, 1838, Samuel Smith Gardiner married Susan F. Mott in the mid-1840s, the daughter of Henry Franklin and the widow of William W. Mott. Samuel Smith Gardiner passed away on March 21, 1859.

Samuel Smith Gardiner business management records in the form of accounts, bills, deeds, estate documents, and statements are included in the Horsford Family Papers (1681-1954) at the Rensselaer Institute Archives and Special Collections in Troy, NY.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group III, Series A, Subseries 1 pertains to Samuel Smith Gardiner's personal and professional life in the form of correspondence, financial records, and legal records. Genres range from clippings, ephemera, handdrawn maps, indentures, invitations, letters, memorandums, receipts, and statements of account. This subseries is dominated by items that capture Samuel Smith Gardiner's professional life through letters with clerks, landowners, lawyers, politicians, solicitors, students, and tenants, featuring business conversations about estate management and execution, farm rentals and sales, and property insurance, maintenance, and transactions in Boston, MA, Long Island and larger New York State, and Ontario, Canada. In addition, this series includes a handwritten transcription of an agreement with the Montauk (Montaukett) Native American tribe concerning East Hampton property in 1702 and twenty-three letters from John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States and first lady Julia Gardiner Tyler, Samuel Smith Gardiner's niece.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Controlaccess
genreform

geogname

Brown, Oliver: Bridgewater, [NY]
Dates:
1823 December 8
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: "Charles T. Dering, Esq., Sag Harbor, Suffolk County," [Long Island, NY]

Lynch Botta, Anne Charlotte: Providence, RI
Dates:
1843 August 26
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Postage

Addressed To: "Samuel Smith Gardiner, Esq., Shelter Island, Suffolk County, Long Island, NY"

Sent From: "Anne Charlotte Lynch [Botta]"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social

3 Pages, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 10"

Anne Charlotte Lynch Botta (November 11, 1815 – March 23, 1891) was an American poet, writer, teacher and socialite whose home was the central gathering place of the literary elite of her era. The Anne Charlotte Lynch Botta Papers (1835-1894) are preserved at the Brown University Library in Providence, RI.

Larrey, Baron Dominique Jean: Paris, France
Dates:
1838 October 10th
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Ephemera

Addressed To: "Madame"

Sent From: "Baron Larrey"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Written in French with "One Lecture on Phrenology, Gev. Combe" Ticket

3 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 2.5" x 1.75" - 5" x 8"

Dominique Jean Larrey (July 8, 1766 – July 25, 1842) was a French surgeon in Napoleon's army and an important innovator in battlefield medicine. Larrey correspondence and personal artifacts are preserved at the Wellcome Museum Library in London, England.

[Legal Correspondence]
Dates:
1837 March - September; 1840 March 3; 1852 October; 1857 February 4

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social

14 Pages, Unbound

Tyler, John: Albany, NY; Norfolk, NY; Richmond, VA; Sherwood Forest, Charles City, VA
Dates:
1853 February 24; 1855 May 27; 1857 March - July; 1858 December 20; 1859 March 15
Scope and Contents

9 Letters with 6 Envelopes, Notation & Seals

Addressed To: "Colonel Samuel Smith Gardiner, Abbey [Sylvester] Manor, Shelter Island, Suffolk County, Long Island, NY"

Sent From: "John Tyler"

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Political / Social; Mr. Boyle of South Carolina; Invitation from the President & Mrs. Tyler

33 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 2.75" - 7.75" x 9.75"

John Tyler (March 29, 1790 – January 18, 1862) was the tenth President of the United States (1841–1845). He was elected vice president on the 1840 Whig ticket with William Henry Harrison, and became president after his running mate's death in April 1841. Harrison's death made Tyler the first vice president to succeed to the presidency without being elected to the office. The personal papers of the Tyler Family can be found at the Special Collections Research Center at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA, while the executive papers of John Tyler while he was Governor of Virginia can be found at the Library of Virginia in Richmond, VA.

Tyler, Julia Gardiner: "President's Mansion" ; Staten Island, NY
Dates:
1845 February 19; 1849 September 29; 1858 August - December
Scope and Contents

7 Letters with 1 Envelope & Notation

Addressed To: "My dear Brother," [David Lion Gardiner]; "My dear Uncle," "Colonel Samuel Smith Gardiner of New York (At Coleman's)," "Shelter Island, Suffolk County, Long Island, NY"

Sent From: "Your affectionate niece" ; "Your affectionate sister, Julia Gardiner Tyler," [Niece of Samuel Smith Gardiner, 2nd wife of President John Tyler]

In Reference To: Family / Personal / Political / Social; Invitation from the President & Mrs. Tyler

21 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 2.5" - 7.75" x 10"

Julia Gardiner Tyler (May 17, 1820 – July 10, 1889) was the second wife of John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States, and served as First Lady of the United States from June 26, 1844 to March 4, 1845. Julia Gardiner Tyler was born in 1820 on Gardiner's Island off the eastern tip of Long Island, New York, one of the largest privately owned islands in the United States. She was the daughter of David Gardiner, a prominent landowner and New York State Senator from 1824 - 1828, and his wife Juliana (née McLachlan). Julia was raised in the New York town of East Hampton as well as in the small hamlet of Bay Shore, Long Island; Bay Shore was called Penataquit until 1868, and even earlier, Awixa. Manuscripts documenting Julia Gardiner Tyler's life are preserved at the Earl Gregg Swem Library at the College of William and Mary, the East Hampton Library, the Library of Congress, the Virginia Historical Society, and the Yale University Library.

Yates, Joseph Christopher: Albany, NY
Dates:
1824 June 2
Scope and Contents

1 Legislature Proclamation with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Honorable Samuel Smith Gardiner, Member of Assembly, County of New York"

Sent From: "Joseph C. Yates, Governor of the State of New York"

In Reference To: Business / Political / Professional; "Require the members of the Senate and Assembly of this state to convene as a legislature, in their respective chambers at the capitol, in the city of Albany, on Monday, the second day of August next at noon"

4 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Joseph Christopher Yates (November 9, 1768 – March 19, 1837) was an American lawyer, politician, statesman, and founding trustee of Union College. Yates' career in government included serving as the first mayor of his birthplace, Schenectady, NY, in addition to the state's seventh governor between 1823-1824, a senator, and a Supreme Court justice. Joseph Christopher Yates is included in the Christopher Yates Papers (1677-1936) at Syracuse University Special Collections Research Center in Syracuse, NY.

Series B: Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner

Scope and Contents

Record Group III, Series B pertains to Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner's personal life in the form of correspondence, financial records, and juvenilia. Genres range from letters and gifts, meeting minutes and receipts, original and collected poetry, to penmanship practice materials, and testimonies of religious faith. This subseries is dominated by items that capture Gardiner's conversations with family members, friends, and school acquaintances in reference to courtship, education, family, faith, marriage, and travel. These exchanges also include those between Mary and Samuel during the events leading up to their marriage. Mary's childhood penmanship practice materials also speak to the writing traditions of the time period.

These materials are lightly arranged alphabetically by surname of the individual in contact with Gardiner or the conversation subject. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Biographical Note

Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner (July 6, 1806 - January 28, 1838) was the only daughter of Ezra and Mary L'Hommedieu. She married Samuel Smith Gardiner in 1823 and gave birth to three daughters: Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner in 1824, Phoebe Dayton Gardiner in 1826, and Frances Eliza Gardiner (Fanny) in 1832. Mary and Phoebe would both marry Eben Norton Horsford, whose personal and professional life are documented in Record Group IV: Horsford Family. Frances married George Martin Lane, a Harvard professor of Latin Language and Literature, in 1857.

Record Group IV: Horsford Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV: Horsford Family preserves the personal and professional materials of Eben Norton Horsford and his immediate family. Series A: Eben Norton Horsford includes record types that range from correspondence, ephemera, financial records, legal documentation, journals, printed materials, and research. While they also include manuscripts and printed materials, Series B - I are dominated by the personal correspondence of Horsford's two wives and five daughters.

Series A: Eben Norton Horsford

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's personal and professional life in the form of eleven different subseries arranged by record type ranging from correspondence in the form of invitations, letters, postcards, and telegrams, Cambridge and Shelter Island estate management documentation in the form of architectural sketches, indentures, and memorandums, financial records in the form of account books, bills, and receipts, patent related circulars, ephemera, and other printed materials, personal and professional writing in the form of collected research, diaries, journals, and notebooks.

Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.

Biographical Note

American chemist Eben Norton Horsford (July 27, 1818 - January 1, 1893), was the only son of missionary and politician Jerediah Horsford and his wife Maria Charity Horsford of Moscow, NY. In addition to Eben, Jerediah and Maria Charity produced four daughters: Maria Horsford Byam, Julia Horsford Norton, Eliza Horsford Tryon, and Laura Horsford.

Eben earned a civil engineering degree from RPI (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute) in 1838 and contributed to the Geographical Survey of New York under the supervision of geologist and RPI paleontologist James Hall. Between 1840 - 1844, Eben lectured at Delaware's Newark College, in addition to teaching mathematics and natural sciences at the Albany Female Academy, where he would meet sisters Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner and Phoebe Dayton Gardiner as students. Between 1844 - 1847, Eben studied with chemist Justus Freiherr von Liebig in Giessen, Germany and returned to the U.S. to marry Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner and serve as the Rumford Professor and Lecturer on the Application of Science to the Useful Arts at Harvard University, where he would steadily publish and teach until 1863.

Mary gave birth to four daughters: Mary Leila (Lilian) in 1848, Mary Katherine (Kate) in 1850, Gertrude Hubbard in 1852, and Mary Gardiner (Mamie) in 1855. Mary died a few months after the birth of Mamie. Eben wed Mary's sister Phoebe in 1857, and the couple produced one daughter, Cornelia Conway Felton, in 1860.

In 1858, Eben founded Rumford Chemical Works with George Francis Wilson, who successfully managed his chemical developments and inventions. Eben's most successful development was the modern formula for baking powder, but he also produced acid phosphate, anti-chlorine, yeast powder, and developed a process for condensing milk. During the American Civil War, Eben devised an "improved army ration" of dehydrated meat; in addition, Rumford generated methods of attaching armor plating to warships, manufacturing fire-proof safes, and water analyses for municipalities in the Boston area.

In 1873, Eben was selected as a member of the U.S. Scientific Commission for the Vienna Exposition. Eben also strongly supported education and professional options for women while becoming Wellesley College's Board of Visitors President in 1877 and honorary class member in 1886. It was also during this time that Eben began researching and publishing work about Viking settlements in America, namely the "lost city of Norumbega," which is believed to be present Weston, MA, in which he had a monument erected in 1889.

The Horsfords led an active social life centered on their Cambridge and Harvard communities. They acquainted with several members of the "Boston Brahmin," in addition to prominent figures of the Cambridge intelligentsia and literary community, including Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr., Henry Longfellow, Sarah Orne Jewett, and Helen Hunt Jackson to name a few.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's personal and professional life in the form of communication with his family, friends, and vast business network. With efforts to separate social and professional content, Subseries 1 is organized by four different subsubseries that feature over 4,243 (10,542 pages) assorted forms of communication that detail distinctive professional projects and or subjects, but there remains a significant amount of overlap. Genres range from announcements, artwork and illustrations, calling / visiting cards, ephemera and printed material in the form of advertisements, clippings, and circulars, collected and original poetry, drafts and reproductions of conversations in the form of handwritten transcriptions and photocopies, financial and legal records, invitations, letters, photographic prints, postcards, research notation, and telegrams.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Subsubseries a: Academic and Family
Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries a: Academic and Family pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's personal and professional life in the form of communication records with his family, friends, and vast business network. While the isolation of subsubseries a: Academic and Family is an effort to separate specific social and commercial content from the rest of Series A, this subsubseries features a significant amount of overlap. Although this portion of Eben's correspondence houses personal communication with his immediate and extended family and or concern of private business, such as Cambridge and Shelter Island property management, these materials also illuminate Eben's childhood, education, and professional ascension in chemistry, food science, and local history.

Academic and Family features over 3,325 letters (8,383 pages) dominated by conversations with local and international academics, professionals across fields of industry, and the general public concerning Eben's public and scholastic circulation of his work with David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary and the history of Viking settlements in America. Genres include announcements, artwork and illustrations, calling / visiting cards, drafts of unsent correspondence, financial and legal records, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters in the form of photocopies and transcriptions, photographic prints, postcards, printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, notices, and telegrams. Eben conversed with renown American and international activists, archaeologists, administrators, architects, astronomers, bibliographers, botanists, chemists, economists, editors, educators, historians, indexers, librarians, ministers, philosophers, physicists, poets, politicians, social reformers, social scientists, theologians, and writers. In addition, this unique set of correspondence demonstrates the Horsford family's active social life among their Cambridge and Harvard communities, several members of the "Boston Brahmin," and prominent figures of the New England literary intelligentsia.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

subject
Harvard University |x History |y 19th century.
geogname
Boston, Massachusetts; New York, NY; Cambridge (Mass.)
Achorny, Sophie Fela: Roslindale [Boston, MA]
Dates:
1889 December 29
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Sophie Fela Achorny"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional

Handwritten in Ink

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Personal / Poetry / Professional; Invitations; "The Princess Charlotte" Poem

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4.25" x 2.25" - 8.25" x 13"

Eben Norton Horsford taught mathematics and natural history at Albany Female Academy from 1840 to 1844; this is also where he met student Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner; they were married in August of 1847.

Anderson, Frimann B: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1889 May 18 - December 31; 1890 January 1
Scope and Contents

7 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor Eben Norton Horsford"

Sent From: "Frimann B. Anderson of 29 Mellen Street / 128 Washington Street, Cambridge," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; Governor Tilden, Mr. Johannes Anderson from Iceland; "Norumbega" lending inquiry; Norse Mythology & Northern Antiquities, the University of Copenhagen, Upsala; Scandinavian Literature; Scandinavian Nationalities, All Norse Association; Translating; "Wanderings of the Vikings" ; These letters appear to be from Frimann B. Anderson, simply a different surname arrangement of [Arugrinnsson]

18 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8.25" - 8" x 10"

Frimann B. Anderson founded the community newspaper "Heimskringla." Anderson worked on the first edition with with Eggert Johannsson and Einar Hjörleifsson, which appeared on September 9, 1886; the publication is currently known as "Lögberg-Heimskringla," and serves the Icelandic community in North America.

Anderson, MB: Rochester, NY

Appleton, John H: London, England

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "John H. Appleton ℅ Trubner & Co., Ludgate Hill, London, England"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Writing; 1 Advertisement Clipping for "Dr. Appleton; His Life and Literary Relics" by John H. Appleton, M.A., Late Vicar of St. Marks, Staplefield, Sussex, [England] & A.H. Sayce, M.A., Fellow of Queen's College & Deputy Professor of Comparative Philology, Oxford, [England] - "will form a volume of 'The English and Foreign Philosophical Library' "

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 8.5"

Appleton, Thomas Gold: Boston, MA
Dates:
1877 April 30
Scope and Contents

1 United States Postal Card with Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "T.G. [Thomas Gold] Appleton by N.A. [Nathan Appleton]"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Committee of Publishing; Mr. Ole Bull

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3"

Thomas Gold Appleton (March 31, 1812 – April 17, 1884), son of merchant Nathan Appleton, was an American art collector, artist, and writer. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow became his brother-in-law after marrying Appleton's sister Frances. The Appleton Family Papers (1539-1941) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Archaeological Society of America: Boston, MA
Dates:
undated, circa 1879 May 21; 1890 May 1

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Annual Meeting at No. 50 State Street (Office of the Treasurer of Harvard College)

Barnard, Frederick Augustus Porter: New York & Scarborough On-Hudson, NY
Dates:
1874 March 28 - December 28; 1875 February 3; 1886 January 21
Scope and Contents

5 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Frederick A.P. [Augustus Porter] Barnard, Columbia College, New York / Scarborough On-Hudson, NY"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; "John Cabot's Landfall in 1497"; Mr. Johnson's "Flour" Article

11 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Frederick Augustus Porter Barnard (May 5, 1809 – April 27, 1889) was a deaf American educator and scientist. Barnard became the 10th president of Columbia College (now Columbia University) in 1864 and held the position until 1888. The Frederick Augustus Porter Barnard Papers (1831-1889) are preserved at Columbia University in New York, NY.

Phineas Taylor Barnum (July 5, 1810 – April 7, 1891) was an American businessman and showman remembered for promoting celebrated hoaxes and for founding the Barnum & Bailey Circus. The Phineas Taylor Barnum Papers (1818-2000) are preserved at Tufts University in Medford / Somerville, near Boston, MA.

Bates, Charlotte Fiske: [Cambridge, MA]
Dates:
1886 December 18
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Charlotte Fiske Bates"

In Reference To: Business / Professional

3 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8"

Charlotte Fiske Bates (Mme. Rogé) (November 30, 1838 – September 1, 1916) was an American writer. Bates published "Risks and Other Poems" (1879) which includes 120 poems, ten sonnets, ten French translations (which were originally done for Longfellow's Poems of Places), and five epithalamia. Bates also contributed many articles to magazines, and edited the Longfellow Birthday Book (1881), Seven Voices of Sympathy(1881), and the Cambridge Book of Poetry and Song(1882). Much of Bates' work is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Baxter, James Phinney: Macworth Island, ME
Dates:
1889 July 3
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation

Addressed To: "Eben Norton Horsford, Esq., Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "James Phinney Baxter"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; "The Problem of the Northmen"

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 7.75"

James Phinney Baxter (1831 - 1921) was an American businessman, civic leader, historian, and benefactor of Portland, Maine. Baxter's personal library of over 100 leather-bound books of maps, portraits, engravings and personal letters, is available for reference at the Portland Public Library in Portland, ME.

Baxter, Sylvester: Boston & Malden, MA
Dates:
1882 February 21 - 1890 July 8
Scope and Contents

15 Letters, 3 United States Letter Sheet Envelopes, 4 United States Postal Cards with Ephemera, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA," "Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Edmund Noble of Boston, MA" ; "Sylvester Baxter, The Boston Herald, 255 Washington Street, Boston, MA," "Ledgewood Terrace, Murray Street, Malden, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Travel; 1 Boston Herald Newspaper Clipping "1529 Map received at state library" ; Charles E. Parsons; News from San Diego; Professor Putnam & Bjornsson; Professor Sayce; Visits to Arizona, Mexico, Providence

32 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 3.25" - 7.75" x 10"

Sylvester Baxter (1850 - 1927) was an American newspaper writer and Boston urban planner. In 1893 he became the first secretary of the Massachusetts Metropolitan Park Commission, and along with Charles Eliot, was a chief force in the development of the Metropolitan Park System of Greater Boston. Many of Baxter's published works are available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Beauchamp, William Martin: Baldwinsville, NY
Dates:
1887 August 22 & September 3
Scope and Contents

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA / Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "W.M. / William M. [Martin] Beauchamp"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Native Americans / Professional; Indian Prayer Book of 1743; Lexicon of German & Oneidas & Onondaga Language; Library of Philadelphia; Study of the Mohawk

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 5" x 8"

William Martin Beauchamp (March 25, 1830 – 1925) was an American ethnologist and Episcopal clergyman. Beauchamp published several works on the archeology and ethnology of the Haudenosaunee (Iroquois) in New York. The William Martin Beauchamp Papers (1840-1944) are preserved at the New York State Library in Albany, NY.

Booth, James Curtis: Philadelphia, PA
Dates:
1844 February 1; 1868 November 1
Scope and Contents

2 Letters with Notation, Postage & Seal

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge," [MA], "Newark, DE"

Sent From: "James C. Booth of Booth & Garrett (Thomas H.), Laboratory for Practical and Analytical Chemistry, Chant Street, Rear of St. Stephen's Church (Tenth Street, Below Market), Established 1836, Philadelphia," [PA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science; Copy of Doremus Testimony; [Education & research of Superphosphate used in agriculture]; Mr. Boyle, Professor Friedrich Wöhler, Gottingen, [Gielsen] with Liebig, Berlin [Germany] with Professor Gustav Magnus, Rose & Mitscherlich

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 8" x 10"

James Curtis Booth (July 28, 1810 – March 21, 1888) was an American chemist who was the melter and refiner at the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia for many years. Booth was born in Philadelphia, was educated at the Hartsville Seminary, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1829, and later studied at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, New York from 1831 to 1832. He visited Germany between 1833 and 1835, spending the year of 1833 in Professor Friedrich Wöhler's private laboratory in Hesse-Cassel, and then spending nine months in the laboratory of Professor Gustav Magnus in Berlin. He opened a chemistry laboratory in Pennsylvania in 1836 for teaching purposes, and when the demand for teaching and chemical analysis increased, he was assisted by Dr. Martin Hans Boyè until 1845. From 1848, Thomas H. Garrett was his associate, and in 1881 the firm became "Booth, Garrett and Blair." The James Curtis Booth Papers (1785-1944) are preserved at the Othmer Library of Chemical History, Chemical Heritage Foundation in Philadelphia, PA.

Borden, A: New Bedford, MA
Dates:
1884 March 15
Scope and Contents

2 Western Union Telegraph Forms

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 5"

Borden [Jr.], Gail: New York, NY & Winsted, CT
Dates:
1863 October 31; 1864 May 27 - November 17; 1865 February 22 & March 6
Scope and Contents

7 Letters with Ephemera & Indentation

Addressed To: "Gail Borden, Esq." ; "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA," "Professor [of] Chemistry, Washington, D.C."

Sent From: "Professor Horsford"; "Gail Borden, Inventor, Brewster's, Putnam County, NY," "Office Borden Condensed Milk Company, Brewsters, South East, NY" & "Winsted, CT"

In Reference To: Business / Chemistry / Food / Politics / Professional / Science; "36-38 Park Row, New York Belting & Parking Company" ; Advertisement Clippings for "Borden's Apple Jelly, or Concentrated Apple Juice" & "Borden's Concentrated Animal Juices by Gail Borden & John H. Currie, for sale by NY Condensed Milk Co., 34 & 36 Elizabeth Street, New York," [NY]; Advertisement "Abraham Lincoln, for President, Andrew Johnson, for Vice-President" ; Animal Food & Beef Extracts, Meat Biscuits & Tea

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 7.75" - 7.75" x 9.75"

Gail Borden, Jr. (November 9, 1801 – January 11, 1874), was a native New Yorker who settled in Texas in 1829, where he worked as a land surveyor, newspaper publisher, and inventor. Borden is most known as the developer of condensed milk in 1853; demand was high for his product by the Union Army during the American Civil War. The Gail Borden Papers (1830-1956) are preserved at the Daughters of the Republic of Texas Library in San Antonio, TX.

Boston Ornamental Iron Works, Bubier & Company: Boston, MA
Dates:
1887 November 15 - December 23
Scope and Contents

4 Letters

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "Bubier of Bubier & Company, Boston Ornamental Iron Works, No. 23 Exchange Street, Works 63 Merrimac Street, Boston," [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional; "Manufacturers of Fountains, Statues, Vases, Lawn Sprinklers, Copper Weather Vanes, Iron & Wire Railings, Iron Stable Fixtures, Iron Crestings"

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.75" x 9.75"

Boston Public Library: Boston, MA
Dates:
1887 April 20; 1889 September 9
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 United States Postal Card with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, [MA]"

Sent From: "Librarian of Bates Hall Arthur M. Knapp, Boston Public Library," [Boston, MA] ; "President of the Board, William [Greenough] & Librarian [Mellen G.]"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Native Americans / Professional; David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 7.5" x 9.75"

Bothne, Gisle [Christian Johnson]: Decorah, IA
Dates:
1889 November 25 & December 10
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge," [MA]

Sent From: "Gisle [Christian Johnson] Bothne"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; Norumbega; The Norse - Chicago papers report of exercises at Watertown, MA

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.5" x 11

Gisle Christian Johnson Bothne (September 7, 1860 - December 8, 1934) was the head of the Scandinavian department of the University of Minnesota from 1907 to 1929. The Gisle Bothne Papers (1896-1934) are preserved at the Minnesota Historical Society in St. Paul, MN and the Luther College Archives in Decorah, IA.

Bradford, Sarah [Hopkins]: New York, NY
Dates:
[no year] February 9 & March 11, circa 1889 - 1890; 1889 December 2; 1890 May 2 & 5
Scope and Contents

5 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Sarah H. [Hopkins] Bradford, 40 West 20th Street / 62 West 55th Street, New York," [NY], "Aurora, NY"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / History / Personal / Professional; Norumbega; Professor [Winchester], Wesleyan University, Middletown, CT

18 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 6.75" - 5" x 8"

Sarah Hopkins Bradford (August 20, 1818 – June 25, 1912) was an American historian and writer. While most of her work consists of children's literature, she is best known today for her two pioneering biographies of Harriet Tubman titled Harriet, The Moses Of Her People (circa 1886) and Scenes in the life of Harriet Tubman (1886), in which multiple versions are available though New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Brewerton, Captain [Henry]: Newport, RI
Dates:
1843 September 3
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany Female Academy, Albany, NY"

Sent From: "Captain [Henry] Brewerton"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Professor [Shorton], Newark, DE

3 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 9.75"

Captain Henry Brewerton (September 25, 1801 – April 17, 1879) was a career engineering officer in the United States Army, serving as the Superintendent of the United States Military Academy and then as a general in the Union Army during the American Civil War. The Brewerton Family Papers (1760-1910) are preserved at the United States Military Academy Library in West Point, NY.

Brewerton, George [Douglas]: Kingston, RI & West Point, NY
Dates:
1842 May 28; 1843 November 14; [no year] September 3, circa 1842 - 1843
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany Female Academy, Albany, NY"

Sent From: "George [Douglas] Brewerton," [Son of Captain Henry Brewerton]

In Reference To: Academic / Education / Family / Friendship / Personal / Social; Miss Watson; Newport, RI; Stockbridge, NY

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 7.5" x 9.75"

Son of Captain Henry Brewerton, George Douglas Brewerton (1827 - 1901) was a noted journalist, painter, and poet. The Brewerton Family Papers (1760 - 1910) are preserved at the United States Military Academy Library in West Point, NY.

Broome, [John] Lloyd: Boston, MA
Dates:
1887 September 4
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "Lloyd Broome, Marine Barracks, Navy Yard, Boston," [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Politics / Professional; Brooklyn; Cemetery Treasury

6 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

John Lloyd Broome (March 8, 1824 – March 8, 1898) was an officer in the United States Marine Corps during the American Civil War. The John Lloyd Broome Papers (1849-1898) are preserved at the United States Marine Corps Museum in Quantico, VA.

Brown, Adelaide: Boston, MA
Dates:
1889 December 3

Brown, Alexander: Nelson County, VA
Dates:
1889 June 4
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Alexander Brown, Norwood P.O., Nelson County, VA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Nelson County History

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.75" x 9"

Alexander "Sandy" Brown (1843 – 1906) was an American historical writer and specialized in the early history of Virginia. Brown served in the Confederate army throughout the American Civil War, and afterward engaged in mercantile pursuits and farming. The Alexander Brown Papers (1815-1910) are preserved at the Earl Gregg Swem Library & Special Collections at The College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, VA.

Bull, Alexander: Boston, MA; France; Germany; Norway
Dates:
1876 November 13; 1880 September 10 - December 24; 1881 July 25; 1889 January 15

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]

In Reference To: Academic / Education / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Bjornson, Edith [Sullivent], Mrs. Jackson, Professor Anderson, Merry Christmas; Dr. Doremus; "[D.R. von Kuczrorvski, 22 Victoriastrabe III, Dresden, Germany]" ; Mr. Longfellow, Mrs. Fields; Ole Bull's Children; Mrs. Edwin Houghton; Pianist Rubenstein

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 7" - 7" x 8.5"

Bull, Sara [Chapman Thorp]: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1884 June 21; 1887 October 17; 1889 July 1; undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

11 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Sara [Chapman Thorp] Bull, 168 Brattle Street / Elmwood," [Cambridge, MA], "Gervania at Sea"

In Reference To: Business / Friendship / Personal / Professional / Social / Travel; King of Norway; Mr. Aldrich; Mr. Hale; Mr. Mitchells; Mr. Nicolaysen Christiania; Miss Whitney

26 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5" x 8"

Sara Chapman Thorp Bull (1850 – 1911) was an American philanthropist and writer. Bull was a dedicated disciple of Swami Vivekananda and was married to Ole Bull, a Norwegian violinist. The Sara Bull Papers (1830-1910) are preserved at The Cambridge Historical Society Special Collections in Cambridge, MA.

3 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5" x 8.5" - 8.25" x 5"

Cabot, [James] Elliot: Brookline, MA
Dates:
1887 December 9
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "J. Elliot Cabot"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; "John Cabot's Landfall," Boston, MA

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6"

James Elliot Cabot (June 18, 1821 – January 16, 1903) was an American author and philosopher. Born in Boston, Cabot attended and taught at Harvard; he was a transcendentalist, edited the Massachusetts Quarterly Review, and wrote a biography of Ralph Waldo Emerson. The Cabot Family Papers (1786-1945) are preserved in the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Studies, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Carr, Ezra Slocum: Castleton, VT; Cherry Valley, Lockport, New Berlin & Onondaga Hollow, NY
Dates:
1838 November 15 - 1844 June 20; 1882 December 31
Scope and Contents

14 Letters with Indentation, Notation, Postage & Seals

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Assistant State Geologist] Albany, NY," "State Geologist, Moscow, Livingston County, NY"

Sent From: "Ezra Slocum Carr," "Ezra & Jeanne Carr, Pasadena, Los Angeles," [CA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / Personal / Professional; Albany Female Academy; Castleton Medical College; Onondaga Academy

43 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 8" - 8" x 10"

Dr. Ezra Slocum Carr (March 9, 1819 - November 27, 1894) was originally trained as a medical doctor but taught in several scientific fields including agriculture and natural sciences. Carr taught at the University of California at Berkeley and the University Wisconsin, in which he also served on the Board of Regents. One-time California Superintendent of Public Instruction, Carr was a progressive educator, friend, and mentor to John Muir, the Scottish-American naturalist, author, and early advocate of wilderness preservation in the United States. The Carr Family Collection (1870-1936) is preserved at the Pasadena Museum of History Research Library and Archives in Pasadena, CA. In addition, The Papers of Jeanne C. Smith Carr (1842-1903), Ezra's wife, are preserved at the Huntington Library in San Marino, CA.

Cartwright, AS: Shelter Island, NY

Chester, Joseph Lemuel: Brooklyn & New York, NY
Dates:
1839 January 17 - July 17; 1840 June 29, [no year] July 9, circa 1839 - 1840
Scope and Contents

11 Letters with Indentation, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., 29 North Pearl Street, Albany, NY / Moscow, Livingston County, NY"

Sent From: "Joseph [Lemuel] Chester, No. 63 Cedar Street / No. 110 Liberty Street / Copier & Conveyancer, Office of John B. Seales, Esq., No. 20 Chambers Street," [New York, NY]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Friendship / Personal / Professional / Social; American Hotel; Sing-Sing; Mr. Brooks; Catherine, Kate Hubbard; Mrs. Chester; N.G. Brooks of the Baltimore Museum; "The Knickerbocker"

30 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 9.75" - 7.5" x 12.25"

Joseph Lemuel Chester (April 30, 1821 – May 26, 1882) was an American anti-slavery spokesman, City Council member, educator, genealogist, poet and writer. The Joseph Lemuel Chester Papers (1843-1880) are preserved at the Woodson Research Center of Fondren Library, Rice University, in Houston, TX.

Reynell Coates (December 10, 1802 – April 27, 1886) was an American educator, poet, physician, and scientist. The Coates and Reynell Family Papers (1677-1930) are preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, PA.

Charles Carleton Coffin (July 26, 1823 – March 2, 1896) was an American author, Civil War correspondent, journalist and politician. The Charles Carleton Coffin Papers (1861-1890) are preserved at the New England Historical Genealogical Society in Boston, MA.

Scope and Contents

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / Personal / Professional / Science; Astronomy; Chemistry Department; Mr. Packer; Mrs. Bull; Mrs. Robins; Richmond & Lee

Crosby, Howard: New York, NY
Dates:
1889 September 17

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 2.25" x 2.75" - 5" x 7.75"

Crowninshield, Mary Bradford: New York, NY
Dates:
1887 January 2
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Mary Bradford Crowninshield, 3 Livingston Place, Stuyvesant Square, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; "John Cabot's Landfall"

4 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Mary Bradford Crowninshield (April 1844 - October 14, 1913) was an American children's fiction writer. Mary was the daughter of American writer Sarah Elizabeth Hopkins Bradford and prominent New York attorney John Melancthon Bradford, Jr. Mary married naval officer Arent Schuyler Crowninshield who saw combat during the American Civil War, advanced to Rear Admiral rank, and worked for the Bureau of Navigation. The Crowninshield Family Papers (1697-1909) are preserved at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, MA.

Cushing, Frank Hamilton: Massachusetts; New Mexico; Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1883 October 23; 1884 October 4; 1886 April 22 & May 18; 1887 February 20
Scope and Contents

5 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Frank Hamilton Cushing, 40 Mt. Vernon Street, Boston, MA," "1507 Rhode Island Avenue, Washington, D.C.," "Camp Augustus (near Tempe), Rio Salado, AZ," "Old Farm, Readville, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / Native Americans / Professional; Anthropology & Archaeology, Primitive Cultures; Cambridge, Wellesley College & Museum; Miss Cornelia; Mrs. Hemenway; Shelter Island; Zuni Tribe

23 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 7.5" - 8" x 10"

Frank Hamilton Cushing (July 22, 1857 – April 10, 1900) was an American anthropologist and ethnologist. Cushing's pioneering studies of the Native American Zuni tribe of New Mexico by entering into their culture helped establish participant observation as a common anthropological research strategy. The Frank Hamilton Cushing Papers (1876-1892) are preserved at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University, New Haven, CT.

Dammer, Dr. Otto: Berlin, Germany
Dates:
1875 May 13
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "Dr. Otto Dammer, Konversations-Lexikon, III. Auflage, Publishers, Bibliographic Institute, Leipzig, Berlin South, Skalitzer Strasse 44," [Germany]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; In German Language

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 9"

Johann Gustav Eduard Otto Dammer (April 20, 1839 - October 18, 1916) was a German chemist, lexicographer, journalist and politician. Documents about Otto Dammer are preserved in the International Institute of Social History in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Dana, James [Dwight]: New Haven, CT
Dates:
1843 September 6
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Albany, NY"

Sent From: "James D. [Dwight] Dana"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; Boston National History Society, [P. Couthory], Professor [Sillman]

4 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 9.75"

James Dwight Dana (February 12, 1813 – April 14, 1895) was an American geologist, mineralogist, volcanologist, and zoologist. Dana made pioneering studies of mountain-building, volcanic activity, and the origin and structure of continents and oceans around the world. The Dana Family Papers (1805-1961) are preserved at the Sterling Memorial Library Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University in New Haven, CT.

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4" x 7" - 5.75" x 9.25"

Davis, [Nicholas] Darnell: Dover, England
Dates:
1887 April 22
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "[Nicholas] Darnell Davis, 22 Victoria Park, Dover, England"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; History of Barbados - "The Cavaliers and Roundheads of Barbados, Harvard University Library"

10 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8"

Historian Nicholas Darnell Davis (1846 - 1915) was born in Grenada, and spent brief periods in Mauritius and Sierra Leone, but his main public career was in British Guiana [Guyana], where he served as Postmaster General (1876-1881), Comptroller of Customs (1881-1895), and Auditor-General (1895-1908). Davis had a life-long interest in the history of the West Indies and more specifically of Barbados; he contributed many historical articles to newspapers and periodicals in British Guiana, Barbados and the United States. The Nicholas Darnell Davis Collection (1752-1915) is preserved at the Royal Commonwealth Society Library, Cambridge University in England.

Deane, Charles with Charles Avery Doremus: Cambridge, MA; New York, NY
Dates:
1885 November 5; 1887 April 19, June 2, November 16 & 28
Scope and Contents

5 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Charles Deane, 80 Sparks Street, Cambridge, MA" ; "Charles [Avery] Doremus, The College of the City of New York, Corner of Lexington Avenue & 23rd Street, New York, NY," "92 Lexington Avenue," [New York, NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Native Americans / Professional / Science; New England Indian Names, Dr. Lach; David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary; Mr. Havemeyer; "Sugar Chemist," Massachusetts Medico-Legal Society

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5" x 8"

Charles Avery Doremus (September 6, 1851 – December 2, 1925) was an American chemist. Charles was the son of chemist and physician Robert Ogden Doremus, and studied the College of the City of New York and at the universities of Leipzig and Heidelberg. Charles was a holder of patents for a process for softening water, a gas furnace, producing hydrofluoric acid, extracting alumina from clay, and for the extraction of potash from feldspar. William Nelson's Genealogy of the Doremus Family is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 3" - 4.5" x 7"

Benjamin Franklin De Costa (July 10, 1831 – November 4, 1904) was an American clergyman and historical writer. The Papers of Benjamin Franklin De Costa (1869-1878) are preserved at the Luther College Archives in Decorah, IA.

Dewey, Chester: Pittsfield, MA; Rochester, NY
Dates:
1837 April 28; 1843 September 5; 1862 November 3 & December 6; 1863 February 25

12 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 12.5"

Chester Dewey(October 25, 1784 – December 15, 1867) was an American botanist, clergyman and educator. The Chester Dewey Papers (1810-1877) are preserved at the River Campus Libraries, University of Rochester, in Rochester, NY.

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Typed, Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 3" - 8.5" x 11"

Melville (Melvil) Louis Kossuth Dewey (December 10, 1851 – December 26, 1931) was an American educator, librarian, and inventor of the Dewey Decimal System of library classification. The Melvil Dewey Papers (1870-1931) are preserved at the Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library in New York, NY.
