Doremus, Estelle [Emma Skidmore]: [New York, NY]
Dates:
1887 October 9; 1889 December 29
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Estelle [Emma Skidmore] Doremus, 241 Madison Avenue," [New York, NY], [Possibly Estelle Emma Skidmore Doremus or her daugher, musician Estelle E. Doremus]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; "Collection of Mr. Barbon" ; Mary Leila (Lilian) Horsford

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6" - 4.5" x 7"

Estelle Emma Skidmore Doremus (May 6, 1830 – May 21, 1905) was the daughter of Hubbard Skidmore, who served in the American Revolutionary War, and became a charter member and honorary vice president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR). Estelle was also a charter officer and regent of the New York City chapter of the DAR (1892 - 1894). The wife of U.S. chemist Robert Ogden Doremus, Estelle was a leading member of the American community in Paris during the height of the Second French Empire. William Nelson's Genealogy of the Doremus Family is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Doremus, Robert Ogden: New York, NY
Dates:
1889 July 6 & 10
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge / Lenox, MA"

Sent From: "R. [Robert] Ogden Doremus, The College of the City of New York, Corner of Lexington Avenue and 23rd Street, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science; Mr. Kinney; Phosphate of Ammonia; Rumford Chemical Works; "The Northmen on our Coast"

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Robert Ogden Doremus (January 11, 1824 – March 22, 1906) was an American chemist and physician. Doremus studied at Columbia University and graduated from New York University in 1842 where he came under the influence of John W. Draper; in 1843 he became Draper's assistant for seven years and aided him in many of his famous researches on light and heat. In 1847 Doremus went to Europe, continuing his chemical studies in Paris with special reference to electrometallurgy, also visiting the establishments where chemical products were manufactured. Doremus married Estelle Emma Skidmore Doremus in 1850. William Nelson's Genealogy of the Doremus Family is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Doty, Lockwood Lyon: Albany, NY

1860 July 16

[Dubben, F]: Bremen, Germany
Dates:
1890 August 13
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Merchants Map

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Villa Teresa, Carlsbad," [Karlsbad (Baden), Germany]

Sent From: "F. Dubben, Norddeutscher, Abthielung [Transatlantic] Passage, Lloyd, Bremen," [Germany]

In Reference To: Business / Professional / Travel; 1 Merchant's Map "Saale, Captain H. Richter"

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 8.5" x 11" - 17" x 8.5"

Norddeutscher Lloyd (NDL) (North German Lloyd) was a German shipping company. It was founded by Hermann Henrich Meier and Eduard Crüsemann in Bremen on February 20, 1857. N.D.L. developed into one of the most important German shipping companies of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and was instrumental in the economic development of Bremen and Bremerhaven.

Eaton, Amos: Troy, NY
Dates:
1837 July 11, September; 1838 February 9, March 17 & 28
Scope and Contents

5 Letters with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Caleb Johnson, Esq., Troy, NY" ; "Dr. [P.R. Beck], Albany Academy, Albany" [NY] ; "Mr. E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Moscow, Livingston County, NY" ; "Mr. [Rawdon] & Mr. Clarke, State Street, Albany," [NY]

Sent From: "Amos Eaton, Rensselaer Institute, Troy," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; John Constable; Mr. McMartin; Recommendations for Eben Norton Horsford

11 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7" x 8" - 8" x 10"

Amos Eaton (May 17, 1776 – 10 May 10, 1842) was an American botanist, geologist, and educator. Eaton is considered the founder of the modern scientific prospectus in education, which was a radical departure from the American liberal arts tradition of classics, religion, lecture, and recitation. In 1824, Eaton co-founded the Rensselaer School with Stephen van Rensselaer III. Eaton's botany teaching laboratory in the 1820s was the first of its kind in the country; his popular lectures and writings inspired numerous thinkers, in particular women, whom he encouraged to attend his public talks on experimental philosophy. The Amos Eaton Papers (1797-1846) are preserved at the New York State Library Manuscripts and Special Collections in Albany, NY.

Eaton, LA: Malden, MA

Edgerton [Merrill], Winifred: [New York, NY]
Dates:
1887 April 12
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Winifred Edgerton [Merrill], 267 West 14th Street," [New York, NY]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Miss [Alice Elvira] Freeman [Palmer]

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6"

Winifred Edgerton Merrill (September 24, 1862 – September 6, 1951) was the first American woman to receive a Ph.D. in mathematics. Merrill's professional life is preserved in the Helen Brewster Owens Papers & Mary Elizabeth Williams Papers at the Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe College in Cambridge, MA and the Mathematics History Department at Wellesley College Archives in Wellesley, MA.

Eliot, Charles [William]: Boston, MA
Dates:
1876 July 1; [no year] January 27, circa 1876
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Charles [William] Eliot, The Household Art Company, 158 Tremont Street, Boston," [MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6" - 5.25" x 8"

Charles William Eliot (March 20, 1834 – August 22, 1926) was an American academic and Harvard's president in 1869. Eliot served until 1909, having the longest term as president in the university's history. Eliot was also a cousin of the Nobel Prize-winning poet T.S. Eliot. The Charles William Eliot Papers (1834-1926) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

Elwyn, Alfred Langdon: Philadelphia, PA
Dates:
1849 September 20 - 1850 November 5
Scope and Contents

12 Letters with Indentation & Postage

Addressed To: "Dr. Alfred Langdon [Elwyre], M.D., [Treasurer of the A. Association]"

Sent From: "E.N. [Eben Norton Horsford], Boston Cambridge," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / Professional; Dr. Jeffries Wyman; Mr. Parkhurst; Professor Wilson of the Royal Commission; Professor Henry for the Smithsonian; Professor Parsons; The Traveller

29 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8" - 8" x 9.75"

Alfred Langdon Elwyn (July 9, 1804 – March 15, 1884) was an author, non-practicing physician, philanthropist, and pioneer in the training and care of mentally disabled in the U.S. Elwyn was one of the founding officers and president of the Pennsylvania Institution for the Blind in 1833. Elwyn also led a Pennsylvania agricultural society and farm school, and was treasurer of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (1849-1870). The town of Elwyn, PA and the care and training facility Elwyn are named for Alfred Elwyn. The Elwyn Historical Archives, The Archives and Library on Disability are preserved at the University of Colorado in Boulder, CO.

Ericsson, [Captain John]: New York, NY
Dates:
1862 June 11 - 1863 January 13; 1866 May 12, 19 & June 4; 1878 June 5; undated, circa 1862
Scope and Contents

7 Letters, 2 Envelopes, with Ephemera, Indentation, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: [Captain John Ericsson] ; "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "[Captain John] Ericsson"; "Charles Gould, Esq., New York," [NY] ; "John B. Kitching, Esq.," [New York, NY]; "Professor Horsford, Chairman of the Rumford Committee of the American Academy of Arts & Sciences, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science / Technology; "Rumford Premium Prize" Address Clippings with Notation, "Awarded to Captain John Ericsson for his improvements in the Management of Heat [Hot Air Engine], by the American Academy of Arts & Sciences, 1862"

17 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 2.75" - 8" x 9.75"

Captain John Ericsson (July 31, 1803 – March 8, 1889) was a Swedish-American inventor and mechanical engineer. Ericsson was born at Långbanshyttan in Värmland, Sweden, but primarily came to be active in England and the United States. Ericsson is remembered best for designing the steam locomotive Novelty (in partnership with engineer John Braithwaite) and the ironclad ship U.S.S. Monitor. William Conant Church's The Life of John Ericsson is available at New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Ernst, CW: Boston, MA
Dates:
1887 September 7; 1890 January 20 & 23

Espy, James [Pollard]: Boston, MA; Washington, DC
Dates:
1841 October 26; 1842 November 26; 1844 February 18
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation, Notation and Postage Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany, NY" Sent From: "J.P.E." / "James P. Espy, Washington City" In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / Professional; "Lecture at Amherst," Secretary of War, National Institution 5 Pages, Bound and Unbound Handwritten in Ink Measurements: 7.75" x 10" James Pollard Espy (the Storm King) (May 9, 1785 – January 24, 1860) was an American meteorologist. Espy developed a convection theory of storms, explaining it in 1836 before the American Philosophical Society and in 1840 before the French Académie des Sciences and the British Royal Society. Espy's theory was published by in 1840 as The Philosophy of Storms; he became meteorologist to the War (1842) and Navy (1848) departments and developed the use of the telegraph in assembling weather observation data by which he studied the progress of storms and laid the basis for scientific weather forecasting. Espy's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Everett, Edward: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1847 February 19; 1849 January 16
Scope and Contents

2 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Edward Everett"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / Personal / Professional; Lowell Institute, Mr. J.A. Lowell; Rumford Professor by the Trustees

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6.25" - 7.75" x 9.75"

Edward Everett (April 11, 1794 – January 15, 1865) was an American educator, diplomat, orator, pastor, and politician. Everett, a Whig, served as U.S. Representative, U.S. Senator, the 15th Governor of Massachusetts, Minister to Great Britain, and United States Secretary of State. Everett also taught at Harvard University and served as its president. Everett was one of the great American orators of the antebellum and Civil War eras. The Edward Everett Papers (1807-1864) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

Field, Cyrus [West]: New York, NY
Dates:
1878 October 12
Scope and Contents

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "President Cyrus [West] Field, The New York Elevated Railroad Company, 145 Broadway, New York," [NY]

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 9"

Cyrus West Field (November 30, 1819 – July 12, 1892) was an American businessman and financier who, along with other entrepreneurs, created the Atlantic Telegraph Company and laid the first telegraph cable across the Atlantic Ocean in 1858. The Cyrus West Field Papers (1819-1892) are preserved at The New York Public Library in New York, NY.

Field, Henry [Martyn]: New York, NY
Dates:
1889 November 22
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Editor & Proprietor Henry M. [Martyn] Field, The Evangelist, 152 Potter Building, Park Row, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Professional; Harvard University

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.75" x 9.25"

Henry Martyn Field (April 3, 1822 – January 26, 1907) was an American author and clergyman. Brother of Cyrus West Field, David Dudley Field II, and Stephen Johnson Field, Henry was born in Stockbridge, Massachusetts. The Field Family Papers (1803-1941) are preserved at the Stockbridge Library Association in Stockbridge, MA.

Fields, Annie Adams: Connecticut, Maine & Massachusetts
Dates:
1881 December 30 - 1893 December 25; undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

20 Letters, 1 United States Postal Card with Ephemera, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Annie [Adams] Fields [with Sarah Orne Jewett], 37 / 148 Charles Street, Boston," [MA], "Manchester-By-The-Sea," [MA], "New London, CT," "South Berwick, ME"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Poetry / Social ; 1 Advertisement Card for "Frank Smith, Wholesale & Retail Dealer in Fruit, Confectionery & Toys, Corner of State & Main Street, New London, CT"

51 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4.5" x 2.75" - 5" x 8"

Annie Adams Fields (June 6, 1834 – January 5, 1915) was an American author, literary hostess, philanthropist, and social reformer. Fields encouraged and formed friendships with some of America's most well-known 19th century writers. Fields archival material can be found at many repositories including Harvard University's Houghton Library in Cambridge, MA, Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA, Simmons College Archives in Boston, MA, and the University of New Hampshire Library in Durham, NH.

1886 May 4, June 8 & 18

Fish, Hamilton: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1876 August 7
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Hamilton Fish, Department of State, Washington," [D.C.]

In Reference To: Business / Professional; Vienna Exposition

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 10"

Hamilton Fish (August 3, 1808 – September 7, 1893) was an American statesman and politician who served as the 16th Governor of NY, a US secretary of state, and senator. Fish was known for his judiciousness and efforts towards reform during the Grant Administration. Fish archival material can be found at many repositories including, but not limited to, the Boston Public Library, Brooklyn Historical Society, Columbia University, Harvard University, Massachusetts Historical Society, New York Public Library, New York State Library, and the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Paul Leicester Ford (March 23, 1865 - May 8, 1902) was an American biographer and novelist. Ford is most known for editing The Writings of Thomas Jefferson. The Paul Leicester Ford Papers (1869-1902) are preserved at the New York Public Library in New York, NY.

Ganong, William Francis: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1889 June 30, November 5, 6, & 24; 1890 February 6
Scope and Contents

5 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "W.F. [William Francis] Ganong, 646 Cambridge Street, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Genealogy / History / Professional; "The Problem of the Northmen"

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 8" x 10"

William Francis Ganong (February 19, 1864 - September 7, 1941) was a Canadian botanist, cartographer, and historian. Ganong's botany career was spent mainly as a professor at Smith College in Northampton, MA, while in his private life he contributed to the historical and geographical understanding of his native New Brunswick, Canada. Ganong's working library is now The Ganong Library at New Brunswick Museum.

Garrison, Wendell Phillips: New York, NY
Dates:
1876 May 2
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "W.P. [Wendell Phillips] Garrison, Office of 'The Nation,' No. 5 Beekman Street, P.O. Box 25, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional; Centennial Exposition

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 7.25"

Wendell Phillips Garrison (1840 – 1907) was an American editor and author. Garrison was the the literary editor of The Nation from 1865 - 1906. The Wendell Phillips Correspondence Collection (1840-1907) is preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, in Cambridge, MA.

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 3.5" x 2.5" - 7.75" x 9.75"

Albert Samuel Gatschet (October 3, 1832 – March 16, 1907) was a Swiss-American ethnologist. Gatschet studied linguistics at the universities of Bern and Berlin, and later moved to the U.S. to study Native American languages. Gatschet became an ethnologist of the U.S. Geological Survey in 1877, and a member of the Smithsonian Institution Bureau of American Ethnology in 1879. Gatschet's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Gaylord, CN: Goshen, CT
Dates:
1889 October 2
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation

Addressed To: "My dear Cousin," [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "C.N. / E.N. Gaylord, Norville Place, Goshen, CT," [Cousin of Eben Norton Horsford]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social; Grandma Buell

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Gibbs, B. Frank: Castile, Moscow & Perry, NY
Dates:
1841 March 25 - 1843 May 9; 1846 July 13, September 16, November 7

Measurements: 7.5" x 9.75" - 7.5" x 12.5"

Gibbs, Oliver Wolcott: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1884 January 11; [no year] May 2, August 21, October 4, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 United States Postal Cards with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Brattle Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "W. [Oliver Wolcott] Gibbs"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Dr. Hofmann; Professor [Pumbfell]

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 5" x 8"

Oliver Wolcott Gibbs (February 21, 1822 – December 9, 1908) was an American chemist. Gibbs is known for performing the first electrogravimetric analysis, namely the reductions of copper and nickel ions to their respective metals. Wolcott Family archival material can be found at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford, CT; Gibbs' work can also be found in New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Gilman, Arthur: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1887 November 12; 1889 August 22
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge," [MA]

Sent From: "Director Arthur Gilman, 5 Waterhouse Street / The Cambridge School For Girls and Young Ladies, Cambridge, MA," "The Longfellow Memorial Association, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Poetry / Professional; "A Lover of Poetry," Philadelphia, PA; "The Problem of the Northmen / Letter to Judge Daly"

2 Pages, Unbound

Typed, Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 7" - 8.5" x 5.5"

Arthur Gilman (June 22, 1837 - December 27, 1909) was an American educator. Gilman and his second wife, Stella Scott Gilman, founded the institution which would eventually become Radcliffe College. The Helen Keller and Arthur Gilman Collection is preserved at the Samuel P. Hayes Research Library at the Perkins School for the Blind in Watertown, MA.

Gilmore, Henry H: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1889 August 24; 1890 January 9
Scope and Contents

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Henry H. Gilmore, Mayor's Office, City Hall, Cambridge," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; "The Problem of the Northmen / Letter to Judge Daly"

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 8.5"

Henry H. Gilmore (August 31, 1832 – December 24, 1891) was a Massachusetts businessman and politician. Gilmore served on the Board of Selectmen of the Town of Medford, MA and as the Mayor of The City of Cambridge, MA.

William Henry Goodyear (1846 - 1923) was an American architectural historian, art historian, and museum curator. The Goodyear Archival Collection (1874-1940) is preserved at the Brooklyn Museum in Brooklyn, NY.

Gowing, Richard: London, England
Dates:
1887 March 14
Scope and Contents

1 Invitation with Notation

Addressed To: "E.B. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "Secretary Richard Gowing, Cobden Club, 6 Upper Park Road, Hampstead, NW," [London, England]

In Reference To: Business / Political / Professional

1 Page, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 9.25"

The Cobden Club was an English political gentlemen's club founded in 1866. The club was a meeting place for believers in the Free Trade doctrine, and was named in honour of Richard Cobden.

Gray, Asa: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1866 May 11 - 18; 1884 March 7 & October 27; undated, circa 1866 - 1888
Scope and Contents

8 Letters, 3 Envelopes with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Dr. Asa Gray" ; "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "E.N. Horsford" ; "President Dr. Asa Gray, American Academy Of Arts & Sciences, Cambridge, MA," "Botanic Garden, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional / Science; Originals & Reproductions, Handwritten Transcriptions; Captain Ericsson; Mr. Charles Gould, The Rumford Committee of the American Academy

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 8" x 10"

Asa Gray (November 18, 1810 – January 30, 1888) is considered the most important American botanist of the 19th century. Gray's Darwiniana was also considered an important explanation of how religion and science were not mutually exclusive. The Asa Gray Papers (1830-1953) are preserved at the Gray Herbarium Library, Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA.

Gray, Asa: Cambridge, MA

1866 May 2 - 16; undated, circa 1866

Edward Everett Hale (April 3, 1822 – June 10, 1909) was an American author, historian and Unitarian minister. Hale archival material is preserved at the Andover-Harvard Theological Library at Harvard Divinity School in Cambridge, MA.

Hall, Fitzedward: Suffolk, England
Dates:
1887 May 16 & June 18
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 United States Postal Card with Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton], Horsford, Esq., Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Fitzedward Hall, D.C.I., Marlesford, Wickham Market, [Suffolk], England"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; London Library

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 4.5" x 7"

Fitzedward Hall (March 21, 1825 - February 1, 1901) was an American Orientalist and philologist. Hall was the first American to edit a Sanskrit text, and was an early collaborator in the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) project. Hall's work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

James Hall (September 12, 1811 – August 7, 1898) was an American geologist and paleontologist. Hall's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Hall, James: Albany, NY
Dates:
1872 April 22; 1881 July 2 - 1882 November 13
Scope and Contents

18 Letters, 1 United States Postal Card with Ephemera, Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Honorable Arthur MacArthur of the Committee of Public Printing of the Senate of New York" ; "James Hall" ; "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Shelter Island, Suffolk County, NY"

Sent From: "E.N. Horsford" ; "James Hall, New York State Museum of Natural History, Albany, NY"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Politics / Professional / Science; 2 Governmental Booklets / Circulars: "State of New York, No. 80, In Senate, Memorial of James Hall, State Geologist, To The Legislature Of The State Of New York with President J.S. Newberry & Recording Secretary O.P. Hubbard" & "State Of New York, No. 88, In Senate, Report Of The Committee On Public Printing Relative To Continuing The Publication Of The Work On The Palaeontology Of The State with Letters From Professor William B. Rogers" ; 1 Newsprint Clipping "Professor Hall the Recipient of a High Honor From the Kingdom of Italy" ; Dr. Murray, Secretary of the Board of Regents

Albert Bushnell Hart (July 1, 1854 – July 16, 1943) was an American educator, historian, and writer. The Papers of Albert Bushnell Hart (1874-1943) are preserved at Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

Hinman, George Wheeler: Oberlin, OH
Dates:
1889 December 16

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

George Wheeler Hinman (November 19, 1864 - March 31, 1927) was an American educator, publisher, and writer. Hinman served as the president of Marietta College in Ohio from 1913 - 1918. Hinman's library is preserved in the Marietta College Library in Marietta, OH.

Holcomb, Amasa: Southwick, MA
Dates:
1844 June 28
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Mr. E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany Female Academy, Albany, NY"

Sent From: "Amasa Holcomb"

In Reference To: Business / Professional / Science / Technology

3 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 9.5"

Amasa Holcomb (1787 - 1875) was an American businessman, civil engineer, farmer, surveyor, and manufacturer of surveying instruments and telescopes. Holcomb archival material can be found in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University in New Haven, CT and the Smithsonian Institute in Washington, D.C.

Holmes, Oliver Wendell: Beverly Farms & Boston, MA
Dates:
1879 July 31; 1886 January 31
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Miss Dering" ; "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "O.W. / Oliver Wendell Holmes"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Social; "The Problem of the Northmen / Letter to Judge Daly," Norumbega, John Cabot's Landfall in 1497

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 6" - 4.5" x 7"

Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr. (August 29, 1809 – October 7, 1894) was an American author, lecturer, medical reformer, physician, poet, and professor. Based in Boston, MA, Holmes was a member of the Fireside Poets. The Book & Print Collection of the Holmes Family, also known as the Oliver Wendell Holmes Library, is preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. In addition, Holmes correspondence is available online through Lehigh University's "I Remain: A Digital Archive of Letters, Manuscripts, and Ephemera."

Hooker, Henrietta E: South Hadley, MA
Dates:
[no year] May 4, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Henrietta E. Hooker, Mount Holyoke Seminary, South Hadley, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / Professional / Social; Botany, Zoology, Physiology, Dr. Asa Gray, Cambridge Botanical Gardens, "Mary Lyon Fund"

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

[no year] January 27, circa 1880s

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany, NY," "Cambridge, MA," "Delaware College, Newark, DE," "Goshen, CT," "Shelter Island, Suffolk County, NY," "United States Hotel, Philadelphia, PA"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel

112 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 2.5" - 8.5" x 4"

Alvah Hovey (1820 - 1903) was an American author and theologian. Hovey archival material is preserved at the Andover Newton Theological School in Newton Centre, MA. Hovey's works are also available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Howells, William Dean: Boston, MA
Dates:
1879 February 28; 1882 February 22; 1884 December 13; 1885 March 31
Scope and Contents

4 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "W.D. [William Dean] Howell, 302 Beacon Street / Editorial Office Of The Atlantic Monthly, Winthrop Square, Boston," [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Professional

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5" x 8"

William Dean Howells (March 1, 1837 – May 11, 1920) was an American realist author, literary critic, and playwright. Nicknamed "The Dean of American Letters," Howells was known for his tenure as editor of the Atlantic Monthly. Howells archival material is preserved at many repositories including but not limited to, Columbia University Library in New York, NY, the University of Rochester Library in Rochester, NY, and University of Virginia Library in Charlottesville, VA.

Hubbard, Gardiner Greene: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1856 March 28; 1861 November 20; 1862 January 24 & 27; [no year] January 25, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

Sent From: "Gardiner G. [Greene] Hubbard" ; "William Wickham, Cutchogue," [NY]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Friendship / Legal / Personal / Professional / Social; Documentation in reference to Samuel Smith Gardiner Estate with Patrick Burns, 3 Inventory Lists, 1 Property Agreement, 1 Memorandum, Signed in the Presence of Daniel M. Lord

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4" x 9" - 7.75" x 12.5"

Gardiner Greene Hubbard (August 25, 1822 – December 11, 1897) was an American financier, lawyer, and philanthropist. The Hubbard Family Papers (1639-1925) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Alpheus Hyatt (April 5, 1838 – January 15, 1902) was an American educator, naturalist, and paleontologist. The Alpheus Hyatt II Papers (1854-1958) are preserved at Syracuse University Special Collections in Syracuse, NY.

Charles Thomas Jackson (June 21, 1805 – August 28, 1880) was an American physician and scientist who was active in chemistry, geology, medicine, and mineralogy. Jackson's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Helen Maria Hunt Jackson, (née Fiske) (October 15, 1830 – August 12, 1885), was an American activist, poet, and writer. Jackson archival material is preserved at Jones Library in Amherst, MA and Tutt Library, Colorado College in Colorado Springs, CO.

James, William: [Cambridge, MA]
Dates:
1876 January 14; 1888 March 28; [no year] January 4, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

3 Letters

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "William James, 18 Garden Street / Quincy Street," [Cambridge, MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; "Society of Psychological Research"

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

William James (January 11, 1842 – August 26, 1910) was an American philosopher, physician, and psychologist. Son of Henry James, Sr., Swedenborgian theologian, William James was the first educator to offer a psychology course in the United States, and one of the leading thinkers of the late 19th century. The William James Papers (1842-1910) are preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, in Cambridge, MA.

Jewett, Sarah Orne: Maine & Massachusetts
Dates:
1880 November 15 - 1888 December 9; undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

23 Letters, 1 Calling / Visiting Card, 1 Cyanotype

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "S.O.J. / Miss Sarah O. [Orne] Jewett with A.F. [Annie Adams Fields], 34 Union Park / 148 Charles Street, Boston, MA," "Manchester-By-The-Sea," [MA], "Newichawannock Canal, South Berwick, ME"

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; 1 Photographic Print on Cardstock featuring 2 Adult Males with 1 Child upon Latin American sculpture; John Greenleaf Whittier

78 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 3.75" x 2.75" - 5" x 8"

Sarah Orne Jewett (September 3, 1849 – June 24, 1909) was an American novelist, short story writer, and poet. Jewett is recognized as an important practitioner of American literary regionalism. Jewett archival material can be found at many repositories including but not limited to Bowdoin College in Brunswick, ME, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA, and the Sarah Orne Jewett House Museum and Visitor Center in South Berwick, ME.

Dates:
1887 February 5

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

1 Page, Unbound

Typed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 8.5"

John Hume Kedzie (1815 - 1903) was an American lawyer, politician, and real estate developer. Kedzie Avenue on the Chicago's West Side and Kedzie Street in Evanston, IL are named for John Hume Kedzie.

Kentarō, Count Kaneko: Boston, MA; Tokyo, Japan
Dates:
1889 June 12; undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "K. / Kentaro Kaneko, The St. Botolph Club, 2 Newbury Street, Boston," [MA], "Tokyo," [Japan]

In Reference To: Business / Political / Professional; Emperor the Commissioner, National Assembly; Lenox, MA

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.35" x 8.5"

Count Kaneko Kentarō (February 4, 1853 – May 16, 1942) was a diplomat and statesman in Meiji period Japan. Kentarō studied at Harvard University, and selected correspondence is digitally available at the Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr., Harvard Law School Library Digital Suite website.

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Kopp, Dr. Hermann Franz Moritz: Giessen, Germany
Dates:
1846 March 24
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation & Notation

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "Dr. Hermann [Franz Moritz] Kopp, Professor of Physics & Chemistry, University of Giessen," [Germany]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science; Letter of Recommendation for Eben Norton Horsford

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.5" x 10.75"

Hermann Franz Moritz Kopp (October 30, 1817 – February 20, 1892) was a German chemist. Kopp was born at Hanau, where his father, physician Johann Heinrich Kopp (1777 - 1858), was professor of chemistry, physics, and natural history at the local lyceum. Kopp's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Lanman, Charles Rockwell: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1887 April 18 & 27-28, June 7
Scope and Contents

3 Letters

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "C.R. [Charles Rockwell] Lanman, Harvard College, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Native Americans / Professional; David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary; "Dr. Carl Florenz, Marienstrasse 27 II, Berlin N.W., Prussia"

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 6.75"

Charles Rockwell Lanman (July 8, 1850 - February 20, 1941) was an American educator and Sanskrit language scholar. Lanman archival material can be found at Columbia University in New York, NY, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA, and John Hopkins University in Baltimore, MD.

Lawes, Sir John Bennet: St. Albans, England
Dates:
1870 April 16
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation, Postage & Seal

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA, United States"

Sent From: "[Sir] J.B. [John Bennet] Lawes, Rothamsted Manor, St. Albans," [Hertfordshire, England]

In Reference To: Academic / Agricultural / Business / Education / History / Professional / Science / Technology

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 4.5" x 7.25"

Sir John Bennet Lawes (December 28, 1814 – August 31, 1900), 1st Baronet F.R.S. [Fellow of the Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge], was an English agricultural scientist and entrepreneur. Lawes founded an experimental farm at his home at Rothamsted Manor that eventually became the Rothamsted Experimental Station, where he developed a superphosphate that would mark the beginnings of the chemical fertilizer industry. Lawes archival material is preserved at the Rothamsted Research Library in Harpenden, England, the oldest agricultural research station in the world.

Library of Congress: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1887 April 21; 1889 June 27 & July 26
Scope and Contents

3 Letters / Receipts

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Librarian of Congress, A.R. [Ainsworth Rand] Spofford"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Native Americans / Professional; 3 Book Certificates / Receipts, "David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary of Algonquin & Iroquois" ; "The Problem of the Northmen, A Letter to Judge Daly, The President of the American Geographical Society, on the Opinion of Justin Winsor"

3 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.5" x 11"

Ainsworth Rand Spofford(September 12, 1825 – August 11, 1908) was an American journalist and publisher. Spofford was the sixth Librarian of the United States Congress from 1864 - 1897. The Ainsworth Rand Spofford Papers are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Lodge, Henry Cabot: Nahant, MA

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Henry Cabot Lodge (May 12, 1850 – November 9, 1924) was an American historian and Republican Senator from Massachusetts. The Henry Cabot Lodge Papers (1775-1966) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Longfellow, Alice Mary: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
[no year] May 12, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Alice M. [Mary] Longfellow, 105 Brattle Street," [Cambridge, MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Alice Mary Longfellow (September 22, 1850 – December 7, 1928) was a philanthropist, preservationist, and the eldest surviving daughter of the American poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. Alice is best known as "grave Alice" from her father's poem, "The Children's Hour." Longfellow archival material can be found at the Longfellow National Historic Site in Cambridge, MA.

1882 April 17

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel

3 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7.25"

Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth: Cambridge & Nahant, MA
Dates:
1874 July 22; 1877 June 18; 1878 March 29; 1879 January 20; undated, circa 1870s
Scope and Contents

5 Letters, 3 Envelopes with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "J.J. Fields, 148 Charles Street, Boston," [MA] ; "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., [27] Craigie Street," [Cambridge, MA], "Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "H.W.L. / Henry W. [Wadsworth] Longfellow, Camb. [Cambridge] / Nahant," [MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Mr. Greene

12 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 2.75" - 4.5" x 7"

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (February 27, 1807 – March 24, 1882) was an American educator and poet whose works include "Paul Revere's Ride," The Song of Hiawatha and Evangeline. Longfellow was also one of the five Fireside Poets, and the first American to translate Dante Alighieri's The Divine Comedy. Longfellow archival material is preserved at many repositories including but not limited to the Bowdoin Library in Brunswick, ME, the Harvard College Library in Cambridge, MA, the Longfellow National Historic Site in Cambridge, MA, and the New York Public Library in New York, NY.

Longfellow, William Pitt Preble: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Mr. & Mrs. W.P.P. [William Pitt Preble] Longfellow, 126 Brattle Street," [Cambridge, MA], [Relative of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Science; Scientific Monthly

7 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 2.5" - 5" x 8"

Low, Seth: Brooklyn & New York, NY
Dates:
1886 January 27 & February 18; 1887 January 31 & February 23; 1889 October 31
Scope and Contents

5 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Seth Low, A.A. [Abiel Abbot] Low & Brothers, 31 Burling Slip, New York," [NY], "Brooklyn," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional / Science; Boston Herald, Rumford Chemical Works; Norumbega; Wellesley College

5 Pages, Unbound

Typed, Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 8" x 10.5"

Seth Low (January 18, 1850 – September 17, 1916) was an American educator, municipal reformer, and politician. In addition to serving as the 92nd mayor of New York City, Low was a diplomatic representative of the U.S. and the President of Columbia University. The Seth Low Papers (1870-1930) are preserved at Columbia University in New York, NY.

Lowell, James Russell: Deerfoot Farm, MA
Dates:
1886 March 15
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "J.R. [James Russell] Lowell, Deerfoot Farm," [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Professional / Travel; American Ministries, Spain

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

James Russell Lowell (February 22, 1819 – August 12, 1891) was an American Romantic poet, critic, editor, and diplomat. Lowell is associated with the Fireside Poets, a group of New England writers who were among the first American poets who rivaled the popularity of British poets. The James Russell Lowell Papers are preserved at Houghton Library, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

1887 May 27; 1889 January 23

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 5.5" x 9"

William Pitt Mason (October 12, 1853 - January 25, 1937) was an American chemist, educator, and engineer. The William Pitt Mason Papers (1877-1924) are preserved at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, NY.

McAllister, Matthew Hall: [San Francisco, CA]
Dates:
undated, circa 1861 - 1865
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Notation

Addressed To: "Mr. E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, [James] Lick House," [San Francisco, CA]

Sent From: "[Matthew] Hall McAllister," [Unidentified Location, Possibly San Francisco, CA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 2.75" - 4.25" x 5.25"

Matthew Hall McAllister (October 26, 1800 - December 19, 1865) was an American attorney, judge, and politician in California and Georgia. McAllister archival material is preserved at the Georgia Historical Society in Savannah, GA and the New England Historic Genealogical Society in Boston, MA.

McDougall Brothers with Others: London & Manchester, England
Dates:
1877 April 14; 1880 May 19 & July 19; 1888 March 5
Scope and Contents

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Cambridge, MA"

Edwin D. Mead(1849 - 1937) was an American educator, pacifist, writer, and social reformer of the U.S. and international peace movement. Mead archival material is preserved in the Swarthmore College Peace Collection in Swarthmore, PA.

Millet, Francis Davis: Austria; [In Transit / At Sea]; Romania
Dates:
1873 June 24; [no year] July 30 & August 23, circa 1870s
Scope and Contents

3 Letters, 2 Envelopes with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA," "Shelter Island, Suffolk County, NY, United States of America"

Sent From: "F.D. / [Francis] Frank D. [Davis] Millet, 44 Strada Carolin, Bucharest, Romania," "Headquarters, 1st Division Cossacks, 14th Russian Army Corps, Kustendje, On the Black Sea," "Massachusetts Commission to Vienna Exposition, 6 Franzensbrickenstrasse, Vienna," [Austria]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science / Travel

13 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.75" x 4.5" - 6" x 11"

Francis Davis Millet (November 3, 1848 - April 15, 1912) was an American painter, sculptor, and writer who died in the sinking of the R.M.S. Titanic on April 15, 1912. Millet Family Papers are preserved at the Smithsonian Archives of American Art in Washington, D.C.

Moody, Dwight Lyman: Northfield, MA
Dates:
1885 June 24
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Vice President, D.L. [Dwight Lyman] Moody, Mount Hermon Boys' School, Northfield, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / Professional

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 9"

Dwight Lyman Moody (February 5, 1837 – December 22, 1899) was an American evangelist and publisher. Moody founded the Moody Church, Northfield School, Mount Hermon School (now Northfield Mount Hermon School), the Moody Bible Institute, and Moody Publishers. Moody archival material is preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., the Moody Bible Institute in Chicago, IL, and Yale University in New Haven, CT.

Morgan, Lewis Henry: Massachusetts; Michigan; New York; Rhode Island
Dates:
1864 June 19 - 1881 December 17
Scope and Contents

34 Letters with Indentation, 1 Obituary

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge," [MA]

Sent From: "L.H. [Lewis Henry] Morgan, 26th District, State of New York, Senate Chamber, Albany / Rochester," [NY], "℅ Dr. Caswell, 113 Washington Street, Providence," [RI], "Office of the Morgan Iron Company of Lake Superior, Marquette / Detroit, MI," "Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology, Harvard University, Cambridge / Boston, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Family / Friendship / History / Native Americans / Personal / Political / Professional / Social / Travel; 1 "In Memoriam" Obituary for Lewis Henry Morgan, L.L.D.

103 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 7.75" x 9.75"

Lewis Henry Morgan (November 21, 1818 – December 17, 1881) was a pioneering American anthropologist, railroad lawyer, and social theorist. Morgan is best known for his work on kinship and social structure, theories of social evolution, and ethnography of the Iroquois. Morgan archival material is preserved at the University of Rochester in Rochester, NY.

Dates:
1881 September 5 - 1883 March 22; undated, circa 1880s

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social

55 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Morris Hicky Morgan (1859 - 1910) was professor of classical philology at Harvard University. Morgan's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Richard Cary Morse (1841 - 1926) was an American editor and social worker. The Richard Cary Morse Papers (1841-1961) are preserved within the Kautz Family YMCA Archives at the Elmer L. Andersen Library, University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, MN.

Louise Chandler Moulton (April 10, 1835 - August 10, 1908) was an American author, critic, and poet. The Louise Chandler Moulton Papers (1852-1908) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

1888 January 4 & October 24

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3"

William Wells Newell (1839 - 1907) was an American educator, folklorist, and minister. Newell's work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Handwritten in Ink

Nicolaysen, Nicolay: Kristiania, Norway
Dates:
1889 January 28
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "N. [Nicolay] Nicolaysen," [Kristiania / Christiania, Norway]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8.25"

Nicolay Nicolaysen (January 14, 1817 - January 22, 1911) was a Norwegian archaeologist and Norway's first state employed antiquarian. Nicolaysen is best known for his excavations of the ship burial at Gokstad in 1880. Nicolaysen's work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Norton, Charles Eliot: Ashfield & Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1881 October 26 - 1889 September 7
Scope and Contents

9 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "C.E. [Charles Eliot] Norton, Archaeological Institute of America / Ashfield / Shady Hill," [Cambridge, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / History / Professional; Executive Committee of the Archaeological Institute; [Dr. Froshingham]; "John Cabot's Landfall and the Site of Norumbega," Professor Pierce; Mr. Ayme, Yucatan, Mr. Bandelier; Mr. Baxter, Mr. Cushing; "The Problem of the Northmen"

20 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Charles Eliot Norton (November 16, 1827 – October 21, 1908) was a leading American author, liberal activist, professor of art, progressive social critic and reformer. The Charles Eliot Norton Papers (1845-1908) are preserved at the Houghton Library at Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

Palfrey, John Gorham: [Cambridge, MA]
Dates:
[no year] November 13, circa 1870 - 1881
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "My dear Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "J.G. [John Gorham] Palfrey," [Unidentified Location, Possibly Cambridge, MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 5.5"

John Gorham Palfrey (May 2, 1796 – April 26, 1881) was an American clergyman and historian who served as a U.S. Representative from Massachusetts. As a Unitarian minister, Palfrey played a leading role in the early history of Harvard Divinity School. The Palfrey Family Papers (1713-1915) are preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library in Cambridge, MA.

Parkman, Jr., Francis: Boston, MA
Dates:
1872 October 26; 1885 January 2; 1889 September 20; undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

6 Letters with Reproduction

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "F. [Francis] Parkman, [Jr.], 50 Chestnut Street, Jamaica Plain," [Boston, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; "John Cabot's Landfall, The Site of Norumbega" ; "The Problem of the Northmen"

9 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 2.5" - 8.5" x 11"

Francis Parkman, Jr. (September 16, 1823 – November 8, 1893) is one of the most notable nationalist historians. Parkman was also a leading horticulturist, briefly a Professor of Horticulture at Harvard University and author of several books on the topic. The Francis Parkman Papers (1565-1903) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Andrew Preston Peabody (March 19, 1811 – March 10, 1893) was an American author and clergyman. The Papers of Andrew Preston Peabody (1839-1895) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

Francis Greenwood Peabody (1847 - 1936) was an American minister and professor of theology at Harvard University. Peabody archival material can be found at Harvard University Library in Cambridge, MA.

Richard Luce Pease (1814 - 1868) was a member of one of Martha's Vineyard's oldest and most prominent families. The Richard L. Pease Papers (1802-1888) are preserved at the Martha's Vineyard Museum in Edgartown, MA.

Edward Charles Pickering (July 19, 1846 - February 3, 1919) was an American astronomer and physicist. The Edward Charles Pickering Papers (1847-1922) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

Pio, Louis Albert Francois: Chicago, IL
Dates:
1889 October 29 & November 14
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Boston, MA"

Sent From: "Editor Louis [Albert Francois] Pio, Room 7, Custom House / 'Samfundet,' Illustrated Scandinavian Magazine, 259-263 Randolph Street, Chicago, IL"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; Leif Erikson [Ericson] Monument; "The History of Leif & the Discovery of America"

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.5" x 11"

Louis Albert François Pio (1841 - 1894) was a Danish journalist and socialist political organizer. Pio was one of the principal founders of the Danish worker's movement, and the principal founder of the Danish Social Democratic Party. Pio archival material is preserved at the Arbejdermuseet & Labour Movement Library and Archives in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Potter, Thomas Bayley: London, England
Dates:
1887 November [no day]; 1889 July 31; 1890 April 11
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 1 Circular Invitation

Addressed To: "Dear Sir," [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "Honorary Secretary & Chairman of the Committee, Thomas Bayley Potter, Cobden Club / Reform Club Chambers, 105 Pall Mall, S.W.," [London England] ; "Honorary Secretary to the Testimonial Committee of the Cobden Club, J.S. Leadam, 117 St. George's Square, S.W.," [London, England]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Politics / Professional; Cobden Club Committee's "Special Publication Fund" ; 1 Invitation to the National Liberal Club, Mr. Gladstone's Presentation

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 10.25"

Thomas Bayley Potter, D.L., J.P. (November 29, 1817 – November 6, 1898) was a British Liberal Party politician. Potter founded the Union and Emancipation Society and established the Cobden Club, a political gentlemen's club.

Powell, John Wesley: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1887 April 27 - October 17; 1889 May 1 - September 7; 1890 February 10
Scope and Contents

8 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Chief Clerk, James C. Pilling, Smithsonian Institution, Bureau of Ethnology, Washington, D.C." ; "J.W. [John Wesley] Powell, Smithsonian Institution, Bureau Of Ethnology, Washington, D.C."

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Native Americans / Professional; David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary; Wellesley College, "Alcove of American Native Languages" ; "Problem of the Northmen" ; Norumbega

10 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Typed, Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 7.75" x 9.75"

John Wesley Powell (March 24, 1834 – September 23, 1902) was an American educator, explorer of the American West, geologist, and soldier. Powell served as director of the Smithsonian Institution Bureau of Ethnology until his death. The Smithsonian Institute also preserves Powell's artifacts collection in the Department of Anthropology, National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C.

Powell, LP: Farmington, DE
Dates:
1889 August 14, 20 & 26
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 1 United States Postal Card with Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge / Lenox, MA"

Sent From: "L.P. Powell"

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 7.75" x 9.5"

Frederic Ward Putnam (April 16, 1839 - August 14, 1915) was an American anthropologist. The Frederic Ward Putnam Director Records (1870-1923) are preserved at the Peabody Museum Archives at Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

Quaritch, Bernard A: Boston, MA
Dates:
1890 March 20

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 9"

Bernard Alexander Quaritch (April 23, 1819 – December 17, 1899) was a German-born British bookseller and collector. Quaritch's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Quincy, Jr., Josiah: Boston, MA
Dates:
1848 November 29; 1850 March 4; 1861 May 31
Scope and Contents

3 Letters, 1 Envelope with Indentation, Notation, Postage & Seals

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Josiah Quincy, Mayor of the City of Boston, MA"

In Reference To: Business / Politics / Professional; Lake Cochituate Conveyance

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.25" x 2.25" - 8" x 10"

Josiah Quincy, Jr. (January 17, 1802 – November 2, 1882) was the mayor of Boston (1845-1849), as were his father Josiah Quincy III (1823–1828) and grandson Josiah Quincy (1895–1899). Quincy Family archival material is preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

1889 October 7; [no year] January 14, circa 1890

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Rand, Silas Tertius: Hantsport, Canada
Dates:
1888 December 13
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Dear Sir," [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "S.T.R. / Silas T. [Tertius] Rand," [Father of Harriet Bayfield & Sarah Marcia Rand]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Native Americans / Native Canadians / Professional

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 10.25"

Silas Tertius Rand (May 18, 1810 – October 4, 1889) was a Canadian Baptist clergyman and missionary, ethnologist, linguist, and translator. Rand's focus was the Mi'kmaq people of Maritime Canada. Rand archival material can be found at Acadia University Archives in Nova Scotia, Canada, Mount Allison University in New Brunswick, Canada, the Public Archives of Nova Scotia, Canada, and Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA.

John Codman Ropes (April 28, 1836 - October 28, 1899) was an American military historian and lawyer. The Ropes Family Papers (1734-1952) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Russell, William Eustis: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1887 January 24 & 26
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "William E. [Eustis] Russell, Mayor's Office, City Hall, Cambridge," [MA]

In Reference To: Business / Legal / Politics / Professional

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 8.5"

William Eustis Russell (January 6, 1857 - July 16, 1896) was an American politician. Russell served as the 37th Governor of Massachusetts between 1891-1894, becoming the state's youngest ever elected Governor at age 34. The William Eustis Russell Papers (1846-1920) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Franklin Benjamin Sanborn (December 15, 1831 – February 24, 1917) was an American author, journalist, reformer, and social scientist. The Franklin Benjamin Sanborn Papers (1845-1936) are preserved at the Concord Free Public Library in Concord, MA.

Scudder, Samuel Hubbard: Cambridge, MA

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Measurements: 4" x 6" - 5" x 8"

Samuel Hubbard Scudder (April 13, 1837 – May 17, 1911) was an American entomologist and palaeontologist. Scudder archival material can be found at many institutions including but not limited to, the Smithsonian Institute Archives in Washington, D.C.

Sears, JM: Boston, MA

Shea, John Dawson Gilmary: Elizabeth, NY
Dates:
1887 June 28 - December 18
Scope and Contents

4 Letters

Addressed To: "Dear Sir," "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "John D. [Dawson] Gilmary Shea"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Native Americans / Professional; David Zeisberger's Indian Dictionary; Ethnological Society

7 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

John Dawson Gilmary Shea (July 22, 1824 - February 22, 1892) was an American editor, historian, and writer. Shea's work focused on Native Americans and the history of Roman Catholicism in America. Shea archival material is preserved at many repositories including but not limited to, the Georgetown University Special Collections Research Center in Washington, D.C., the New York Public Library Archives in New York, NY, and the Roesch Library at the University of Dayton in Ohio.

Sigourney, Lydia Huntley: Hartford, CT
Dates:
1843 May 24
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Mr. E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany Female Academy, Albany, NY"

Sent From: "L.H. [Lydia Huntley] Sigourney"

In Reference To: Business / Poetry / Professional / Travel; Mrs. James A. Hillhouse, Miss Mary L. Hillhouse

3 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.5" x 9"

Lydia Huntley Sigourney (née Lydia Howard Huntley), (September 1, 1791 – June 10, 1865), was a popular American poet during the early and mid 19th century. Sigourney archival material is preserved at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford, CT, Mount Holyoke College Archives & Special Collections in South Hadley, MA, and the William L. Clements Library at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, MI.

Silliman, Jr., Benjamin: New Haven, CT
Dates:
1843 November 28; 1844 March 13; 1869 February 2
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation, Notation & Seal

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Albany," [NY], "Cambridge," [MA]

Sent From: "B. [Benjamin] Silliman, Jr., Yale College Laboratory, New Haven," [CT]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science; Dr. Lawrence Smith of Charleston, Professor James Booth of Philadelphia; Rumford Laboratory, Dr. Barker

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Benjamin Silliman, Jr. (December 4, 1816 – January 14, 1885) was a professor of chemistry at Yale University and instrumental in developing the oil industry. The Silliman Family Papers (1717-1977) are preserved at the Sterling Memorial Library at Yale University in New Haven, CT.

John Lawrence Smith (December 17, 1818 – October 12, 1883) was an American chemist, educator, and inventor of the inverted microscope. Smith's work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

1887 February 1 & June 1

Richard Salter Storrs (August 21, 1821 - June 7, 1900) was an American Congregational clergyman. The Richard Salter Storrs Family Collection (1764-1900) is preserved at the Brooklyn Historical Society in Brooklyn, NY.

Talbot, Marion: Boston, MA

[no year] April 19, May 20 & December 20, circa 1880s

3 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Marion Talbot, 66 Marlborough Street," [Boston, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Education / Friendship / History / Personal / Professional / Social / Travel; The Historical Association, Mr. R.T. Paine, Mr. Curtis Guild; Wellesley College

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Marion Talbot (July 31, 1858 – October 20, 1948) was an American educator and influential education reformer. The Marion Talbot Papers (1854-1948) are preserved at the University of Chicago Special Collections Research Center in Chicago, IL.

Taussig, Frank William: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1887 February 26
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Mr. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "F.W. [Frank William] Taussig"

In Reference To: Business / Professional

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Frank William Taussig (December 28, 1859 – November 11, 1940) was an American economist and educator. Taussig is credited with creating the foundations of moderntrade theory. The Frank William Taussig Papers (1890-1946) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

[Vegnaur], Henry: Paris, France

1889 September 4

1 Letter

Sent From: "Henry [Vegnaur], Legation of the United States of America, 59 rue Galilee, Paris," [France]

2 Pages, Bound

Measurements: 8" x 10.5"

von Hofmann, August Wilhelm: London, England
Dates:
1846 April 26
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation & Notation

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "A.W. [August Wilhelm von] Hofmann, Ph.D, Professor of Chemistry, William University at Bonn, [Germany] and Professor at The Royal College of Chemistry, London, Honorary Member of The Royal Agricultural Society of England, 16 Hanover Square, London," [England]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Science; Harvard University

4 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

August Wilhelm von Hofmann (April 8, 1818 – May 5, 1892) was a German chemist. After studying under Justus von Liebig at the University of Giessen, Hofmann became the first director of the Royal College of Chemistry in London in 1845. In 1865, Hofmann returned to Germany to accept a position at the University of Berlin as a teacher and researcher; he also co-founded the German Chemical Society (Deutsche Chemische Gesellschaft) in 1867. In both London and Berlin, Hofmann recreated the style of laboratory instruction established by Liebig at Giessen, fostering a school of chemistry focused on experimental organic chemistry and its industrial applications. Hofmann archival material is preserved at the Imperial College Archives in London, England.

von Liebig, Baron Justus Freiherr: Munich, Germany
Dates:
1868 July 20 - 1888 December 26; undated, circa 1870s - 1880s
Scope and Contents

6 Letters, 5 Envelopes with Indentation, Notation & Postage, 1 Picture Postcard with Ephemera

Addressed To: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Rumford Professor of Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, North America"

Sent From: "[Baron] J. [Justus Freiherr von] Liebig, President of the Bavarian Academy of Sciences, München [Munich], Germany" ; [Georg von Liebig]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Food / Friendship / History / Personal / Professional / Science / Social; 1 Advertisement / Circular, "Extract From A Letter Of Baron Liebig, of Germany, To Professor Horsford," [12 Copies]; Correspondence in English & German Language; "The Problem of the Northmen" ; Correspondence dated after Liebig's death, possibly from Liebig relative or Marie von Liebig

46 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4.5" x 3" - 7" x 8.5"

Baron Justus Freiherr von Liebig (May 12, 1803 – April 18, 1873) was a German chemist. Liebig made significant contributions to agricultural and biological chemistry, and is considered to be the founder of organic chemistry. Liebig's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Sent From: "H. [Heinrich von] Littrow, k.k. Fregatten-Captaine, k. See-Inspector [Frigate Captain], Fiume," [Currently Croatia & since the end of WWII, known as Rijeka]

In Reference To: Business / Professional; In German Language

Printed & Handwritten in Pencil

Measurements: 3.75" x 2.75" - 5.75" x 9"

Heinrich von Littrow (January 26, 1820 – April 25, 1895) was an Austrian cartographer and writer. Littrow's work is available at the German National Library in Frankfurt, Germany.

David Ames Wells (June 17, 1828 – November 5, 1898) was an American author, economist, and engineer. Wells archival material is preserved at the Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA, the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., and the New York Public Library in New York, NY.

In Reference To: Academic / Education / Friendship / History / Personal / Social; American Historical Association; "Champlain's Voyages" ; "Harriet, the Moses of Her People" ; "How I Came By A Berghem by E.N.H. & Souvenir of Wellesley College, 1888" ; Charles River; Houghton, Mifflin & Company; "The Problem of the Northmen / Letter to Judge Daly" ; Wellesley College, Alice Elvira Freeman Palmer

49 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 7.75" x 10"

Justin Winsor (January 2, 1831 – October 22, 1897) was an American historian, librarian, and writer. Winsor's historical work had strong bibliographical and cartographical elements; he was also an authority on the early history of North America. Winsor archival material is preserved at the Houghton Library at Harvard College in Cambridge, MA and the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Robert Charles Winthrop (May 12, 1809 - November 16, 1894) was a descendant of John Winthrop; R.C. Winthrop was an American lawyer, philanthropist and one time Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives. The Winthrop Family Papers (1537-1900) are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Barnabas Wood (May 17, 1819 - May 30, 1875) was an American dentist and inventor best known for his discovery of the fusible alloy known as Wood's metal. Barnabas Wood archival material is preserved at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, TN.

Morrill Wyman (July 25, 1812 – January 30, 1903) was an American physician and social reformer. Wyman is best known today for his work on hay fever. The Wyman Family Archive is preserved at Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

[Newton Darling] Arnold, Treasurer, Providence, RI" ; "Passport Clerk, Washington, D.C." ; "Timothy McGillicuddy, Pittsfield, MA" ; "Tom, Hartford, CT" ; "Wellesley, MA"

In Reference To: Business / Family / Financial / Friendship / Legal / Personal / Professional; 1 Photocopy of Wellesley Telegraph Form; Miss Aldrich

14 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 5.5" - 11" x 8.5"

Subsubseries b: Wellesley College
Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries b, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's professional life in the form of communication with Wellesley administrators, faculty, staff, and students, in addition to American academics and professionals from across the nation. Subsubseries b features documentation in the form of calling / visiting cards, drafts of unsent correspondence, handwritten flyers, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters in the form of photocopies and transcriptions, postcards, printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, notices, and statements for circulation among the general public, and telegrams.

Subsubseries b features over 109 letters (179 pages) from Wellesley founders Henry Fowle Durant and Pauline Adeline Fowle Durant. Records preserved in this subsubseries trace Horsford's work as the Wellesley board of visitors president in which he conversed with American activists, architects, astronomers, bibliographers, botanists, economists, editors, educators, historians, indexers, librarians, ministers, philosophers, physicists, social reformers, social scientists, theologians, and writers. In addition, this unique set of correspondence demonstrates Horsford's friendships and professional relationships with first wave feminists, pioneers of higher education for women, and women's suffrage supporters including, but not limited to, Ada Howard, Alice Elvira Freeman Palmer, Alice Upton Pearmain, Helen Barrett Montgomery, Katharine Lee Bates (author of the words to "America the Beautiful"), Katharine Coman, Leila S. McKee, Sarah Frances Whiting, Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge, and Susan Hallowell.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Historical Note

Wellesley College is a private women's liberal-arts college in the town of Wellesley, west of Boston, MA, and member of the original Seven Sisters Colleges. Henry Fowle Durant and his wife Pauline Adeline Fowle Durant founded Wellesley in 1870. Massachusetts Governor William Claflin signed Wellesley's charter on March 17, 1870 as Wellesley Female Seminary; the Massachusetts legislature approved the institution's name change to Wellesley College on March 7, 1873, although it did not open its doors to students until September 8, 1875.

Like the Durants, Eben Norton Horsford was an advocate and supporter of educational opportunities for women. Horsford became the president of the Wellesley College board of visitors, and frequently donated funding for institutional maintenance and supplies. Wellesley dedicated Norumbega Hall in Horsford's honor in 1886, and was celebrated by the John Greenleaf Whittier poem of the same name.

Notable Wellesley graduates include astronomer Annie Jump Cannon (Class of 1884), author Harriet Stratemeyer Adams (Pseudonym Carolyn Keene, Class of 1914), the former first lady of China, Soong May-ling (Madame Chiang Kai-shek, Class of 1917), U.S. Secretaries of State Madeleine Korbel Albright (Class of 1959) and Hillary Rodham Clinton (Class of 1969), screenwriter Nora Ephron (Class of 1962), journalist Diane Sawyer (Class of 1967), author Alexandra Curry (Class of 1979), and astronaut Pamela Melroy (Class of 1983).

This historical note was written with the help of the finding aids of the Wellesley College Archives.

Barrett, Anne Louise: Rochester & Trenton, NY; Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1883 May 23; 1884 August 18; 1889 July 3, 29 & August 31
Scope and Contents

6 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Anne Louise Barrett, 182 Fulton Avenue, Rochester, NY," "South Trenton, Oneida County, NY," "Wellesley, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / History / Professional; Original & Photocopies; Norumbega

13 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 6.75" - 8.5" x 11"

Barrett [Montgomery], Helen M: Philadelphia, PA
Dates:
1886 February 21 & November 22
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Helen M. Barrett [Montgomery], Wellesley School, 2027 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia," [PA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; "The Library Festival at Wellesley College"

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Helen Barrett Montgomery (July 31, 1861 – October 19, 1934) was an American educator, social reformer, and writer. In 1921, Montgomery was elected as the first woman president of the Northern Baptist Convention (and of any religious denomination in the U.S.). Montgomery had long been a delegate to the Convention and a policymaker. In 1893, she helped found a chapter of the Women's Educational and Industrial Union in Rochester, NY, and served as president for nearly two decades. In 1899, Montgomery was the first woman elected to the Rochester School Board and any public office in the city, twenty years before women could vote. Montgomery's published works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Bates, Katharine Lee: Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1886 November 22 & December 30; 1887 August 15, September 22 & October 26
Scope and Contents

5 Letters with Ephemera & Notation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Katharine Lee Bates"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; 1 Newsprint Clipping "The College Beautiful" Poem by Katharine Lee Bates; Originals & Photocopies with Notation; "The Library Festival at Wellesley College"

16 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 2" x 20"

Katharine Lee Bates (August 12, 1859 – March 28, 1929) was an American author, poet and songwriter. Bates is remembered as the author of the words to the anthem "America the Beautiful." Bates was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970 and listed as one of the thirty-one LGBT history icons by the organizers of LGBT History Month in 2012. Bates archival material can be found at the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America, Radcliffe College in Cambridge, MA, Falmouth Historical Society in Falmouth, MA, Houghton Library, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA, and Wellesley College Archives in Wellesley, MA.

"Board of Visitors of Wellesley College" : Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1886 February 15
Scope and Contents

1 United States Postal Card with Postage

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, [27] Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Board of Visitors of Wellesley College," [Wellesley, MA]

Bowne, Borden Parker (BP): Boston, MA
Dates:
1889 December 3; 1890 May 12
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Dean B.P. [Borden Parker], L.L.D., 380 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA," "Boston University, School Of All Sciences, Dean's Office, 12 Somerset Street, Boston," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Wellesley Board of Visitors

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 8.5"

Borden Parker Bowne (January 14, 1847, Leonardville, NJ – April 1, 1910, Boston, MA) was an American Christian philosopher and theologian in the Methodist tradition. In 1876, Bowne became a professor of philosophy at Boston University, where he taught for more than thirty years; he later served as dean of the graduate school. Bowne's published works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Braley, Elizabeth Williams: Cottage City & New Bedford, MA; Nashville, TN; Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1884 November 24 & December 13; 1886 November 14; 1889 July 26 & August 8
Scope and Contents

5 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Honorary Member of the Class of 1886"

Sent From: "Corresponding Secretary, Class of 1886, Elizabeth W. [Williams] Braley," [Possibly correspondence from two different individuals sharing the same name]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional

9 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Breckinridge, Sophonisba Preston: Ocean Beach, NJ
Dates:
1889 August 14
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Sophonisba P. [Preston] Breckinridge, 1920 I Street, [Washington, D.C.] / Ocean Beach, NJ"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional

3 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6"

Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge (April 1, 1866 – July 30, 1948) was an American activist, Progressive Era social reformer, and social scientist. Breckinridge was active in several causes including but not limited to: African American Civil Rights, Children's Protection and Labor Laws Reform, Immigration, Pacifism, Progressive Party, and Women's Suffrage. The Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge Papers (1905-1949) are preserved at the University of Chicago in Chicago, IL, while the Breckinridge Family Papers (1752-1965) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Coman, Katharine: Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1886 February 4

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Katharine Coman"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social

4 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Katharine Coman (November 23, 1857 – January 11, 1915) was a distinguished economist and social activist. Coman specialized in the development of the American West and Wellesley College named a professorship in her honor. Coman's published works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Dates:
1874 September 19 - 1881 July 11

42 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 10"

Henry Fowle Durant (Born Henry Welles Smith) (February 22, 1822 – October 3, 1881) was an American lawyer, philanthropist, and founded Wellesley College in 1870. Henry and Pauline Durant archival material can be found at Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA.
