Fletcher, William Isaac: Amherst, MA
Dates:
1886 June 5
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Dear Sir," [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: "Librarian William I. [Isaac] Fletcher, Library of Amherst College, Amherst, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Miss Hawes, American Library Association, Mr. [Melville] Dewey

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 7.75"

William Isaac Fletcher (April 23, 1844 - June 15, 1917) was an American bibliographer, indexer, and librarian who served as the head librarian of Amherst College from 1883 to 1911. Fletcher also served as the President of the American Library Association from 1891 to 1892. Library Journal added Fletcher to the Library Hall of Fame in 1951. Fletcher's published works are available in New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Ford, Emily Ellsworth: Brooklyn, NY
Dates:
[no year] January 7, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Emily Ellsworth (Fowler) Ford, 97 Clark Street," [Brooklyn, NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 6"

Emily Ellsworth (Fowler) Ford was an American writer. Ford's work was published in a variety of contemporary literary journals, magazines, and newspapers. Ford came from a prominent family, well-connected within both social and literary circles; Ford and Emily Dickinson were childhood friends. The Emily Fowler Ford Papers (1744-1893) are preserved at The New York Public Library in New York, NY.

Freeman Palmer, Alice Elvira: Osborne Hollow, NY; Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1880 December 1 - 1885 April 21
Scope and Contents

33 Letters, 5 United States Postal Cards with Postage, 4 Western Union Telegraph Forms with Notation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Alice E. [Elvira] Freeman [Palmer], Osborne Hollow, NY," "President's Office, Wellesley College, Wellesley, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Invitations & Events Notifications; Originals with Photocopies & Printed Transcriptions

85 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Typed, Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 8.5" x 11"

Alice Elvira Freeman Palmer (February 21, 1855 – December 6, 1902) was an American educator. Freeman was Wellesley College President from 1882 to 1887. Freeman wed Harvard professor George Herbert Palmer in 1887. From 1892 to 1895, she was Dean of Women at the newly founded University of Chicago. Alice Freeman Palmer manuscript material is preserved at Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA.

Gould, Alice B: Jamaica Plain, MA

Gould, Benjamin Apthorp: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
[no year] January 28, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "[Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "B.A. [Benjamin Apthorp] Gould, 29 Kirkland Street, Cambridge," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Thank You for the Wellesley College Invitation

1 Page, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Benjamin Apthorp Gould (September 27, 1824 – November 26, 1896) was a pioneering American astronomer. Gould is noted for creating the Astronomical Journal, discovering the Gould Belt, and for founding of the Argentine National Observatory and the Argentine National Weather Service. Gould archival materials can be found at the New York Public Library in New York, NY, and the University of Puget Sound Archives and Special Collections in Tacoma, WA.

Gould, Ezra Palmer: Newton, MA
Dates:
1878 June 22 & October 11; 1881 November 30
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation & Notation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Secretary Ezra P. [Palmer] Gould per J.F.P., Newton Centre [Newton Theological Institution]," [Newton, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Board of Visitors; Honorable J.W. Dickinson, Boston, MA, A.P. Marble, Worcester, MA, W.S. Houghton, Miss C. Borden of Fall River, Mrs. [Alphens] Hardy

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8.5"

Ezra Palmer Gould (February 27, 1841 – August 22, 1900) was a Baptist and Episcopal minister. Gould graduated Harvard University in 1861 and subsequently served in the American Civil War. Gould entered the ministry in 1868; his commentary on the Gospel of Mark continued to be reprinted in the International Critical Commentary series. Gould's published work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Gray, George and Joseph T. Duryea: [Wellesley, MA]

1886 March 10

Greenough, James Carruthers: Amherst & Westfield, MA
Dates:
1884 May 26; 1887 February 8
Scope and Contents

2 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Chairman of the Board of Visitors, Wellesley College," [Wellesley, MA]

Sent From: "J.C. [James Carruthers] Greenough, Amherst, MA," "State Normal School, Westfield, MA"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Wellesley Board of Visitors

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 8" x 10"

James Carruthers Greenough (August 15, 1829 – December 4, 1924) was an American educator. Greenough served as the third principal of the Rhode Island Normal School, sixth president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College, and seventh principal of the Westfield State Normal School. The James Carruthers Greenough Papers (1854-1887) are preserved at the Special Collections & University Archives at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

1886 January 31; 1887 May 4 - 1888 February 26; [no year] September 20, circa 1886 - 1888

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 3.5" - 5" x 8.25"

Susan Morris Hallowell, (1835 - 1911) was an American botanist and Wellesley College's first Professor of Botany.

Howard, Ada L: Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1877 November 26; 1878 February 5 & October 18; 1881 April 30; 1886 March 15 & May 29
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 United States Postal Cards with Postage, 1 Invitation with Ephemera

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "President, Ada L. Howard (Reverend J.R.F.), Wellesley College," [Wellesley, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; 1 Wellesley College Faculty Bulletin / Circular, Dr. William P. Wesselhoeft; Norumbega; Wellesley College Chapel Concert; Opening of New Organ

13 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3" - 5" x 8"

Ada L. Howard (1829 - 1907) was the first president of Wellesley College, and served between 1875 and 1881. Howard graduated from Mount Holyoke College (then Mount Holyoke Female Seminary) in 1853. Before joining Wellesley, Howard taught at Western College in Ohio and was principal of the Woman's Department of Knox College. The Ada Howard Papers at Wellesley College Archives in Wellesley, MA.

Dates:
1887 June 28 - November 4; 1889 July 18 - December 20

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Financial / Genealogy / History / Native Americans / Professional / Travel; [David Zeisberger's] "Indian Dictionary" ; Gardiners Island; "Lost City of New England" / [Norumbega]; Mrs. Amelia B. Edwards; Sylvester Manor Legal Records / Quitclaim Inquiry; Visiting Shelter Island

28 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 4" x 6.25" - 8.5" x 11"

Martha Joanna Reade Nash Lamb (August 13, 1829 – January 2, 1893) was an American author, editor and historian. The Martha J. Lamb Papers (1838-1969) are preserved in the Sophia Smith Collection at Smith College in Northampton, MA.

McKee, Leila S: Kentucky; Ohio; Massachusetts; Missouri
Dates:
1887 June 16 - 1889 December 18
Scope and Contents

9 Letters

Addressed To: "Our dear Class-Brother," "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Leila S. McKee, Danville, KY," "Kansas City, MO," "South Hadley, MA," "Western Female Seminary, Oxford, OH"

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Mount Holyoke Seminary & College

37 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 5.5" - 7" x 9"

Leila S. McKee (1858 - 1938) was an American education administrator. As second principal and then president of the Western Female Seminary, McKee elevated the institution to a college for women. The Leila McKee Collection (1888-1975) is preserved at the Western College Memorial Archives at Miami University in Miami, FL.

Merrill, Helen Abbot: Massachusetts; New Jersey; New York
Dates:
1883 December 5; 1884 October 8; 1888 July 27 - 1890 February 1
Scope and Contents

11 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Helen A. [Abbot] Merill, 72 Easton Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ," "1961 Madison Avenue, New York, NY," "Class of 1886 Corresponding Secretary, Wellesley College," [Wellesley, MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Anne Barrett, Miss Damon; Dr. Jones, Miss Horton; Nellie Pendleton

35 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Helen Abbot Merrill (1864 – 1949) was an American educator, mathematician, and textbook author. More information about Merrill can be found in Claudia Henrion's Women in Mathematics: The Addition of Difference, which is available in New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Mosman, Mary C: France; Germany; Italy; Scotland; U.S.A.
Dates:
1888 August 21 - 1890 May 20
Scope and Contents

15 Letters with Notation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, [27] Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Mary C. Mosman, 201 Dekalb Avenue, Brooklyn, NY," "208 Washington Park, Brooklyn," [NY], "Auburndale," [FL], "Auflage 39, Heidelberg," [Germany], "Friedelstraße 49 AIII, Berlin," [Germany], "Hotel De La Ville, Naples," [Italy], "Paris, France," "Pension Chapman, Florence, Italy," "Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY," "Regent Hotel, Edinburgh," [Scotland]

Pearmain, Alice Upton: Chelsea, MA
Dates:
1890 March 10
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Alice [Whittemore] Upton Pearmain, Chelsea," [MA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional; Dr. [Alexander] McKenzie; Norumbega Fund

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

Alice Whittemore Upton Pearmain (born July 5, 1863) was an American educator, social worker, and suffragist. Pearmain was the president of Wellesley College Alumnae Association and of the organizations connected with the college. Pearmain family archival material is available online via the Smithsonian Archives of American Art.

Ellen Fitz Pendleton (1864 – 1936) was an American college president. Pendleton archival materials are preserved in the Wellesley College Archives, at the Margaret Clapp Library, in Wellesley, MA.

Helen Almira Shafer (September 23, 1839 - January 20, 1894) was an American educator and president of Wellesley College. Shafer archival materials are preserved in the Wellesley College Archives, at the Margaret Clapp Library, in Wellesley, MA.

Henry Van Brunt (September 5, 1832 – April 8, 1903) was a 19th-century American architect, architectural writer, and FAIF (Fellow of the American Institute of Architects). Van Brunt's published works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Carla Wenckebach was a professor of German at Wellesley College from 1883 to 1902. The Carla Wenckebach Papers are preserved at the Wellesley College Archives in the Margaret Clapp Library in Wellesley, MA.

Whiting, Sarah Frances: Le Roy, NY; Wellesley, MA
Dates:
1881 October 24 & 28; 1883 May 3; 1884 January 24 & December 8
Scope and Contents

7 Letters

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "Sarah F. [Frances] Whiting, 138 / Physical Laboratory, Wellesley College, Wellesley, MA," "Elm Cottage, Le Roy," [NY]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Friendship / Personal / Professional / Social / Travel; Dr. McCork, Philadelphia, PA, Microscopic Society; Miss Hodgkins; Mr. [Henry Fowle] Durant

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Sarah Frances Whiting (August 23, 1847 – September 12, 1927) was an American astronomer, educator, and physicist. Wellesley College president Henry Fowle Durant appointed Whiting as Wellesley College's first professor of physics in 1875. The Sarah Frances Whiting Papers (1859-1927) are preserved in the Wellesley College Archives, at the Margaret Clapp Library in Wellesley, MA.

Whiting, Lilian: Boston, MA
Dates:
1887 November 4
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Subsubseries c: Rumford Chemical Works
Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries c, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's professional life in the form of Rumford Chemical Works interdepartmental communication. Subsubseries c features 137 business documents (183 pages) in the form of correspondence, financial records, and light legal notation. This subseries includes genres such as checks, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters, notifications, legal and patent notation, receipts, and telegrams. In addition, this subsubseries features seventy-three letters (eighty-nine pages) from Rumford general manager, secretary, and treasurer, Newton Darling (N.D.) Arnold; as well as twenty-seven letters (thirty-four pages) from Rumford co-founder George F. Wilson.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Historical Note

Eben Norton Horsford and George Francis Wilson formed Rumford Chemical Works in Seekonk, MA (later East Providence, RI) in 1858. Horsford took the namesake from his Rumford Professorship and Lectureship position at Harvard University, which was named after Benjamin Thompson, Count Rumford (1753-1814), a British physicist, inventor, and social reformer. Rumford Chemical Works included a merger with George Francis Wilson & Company (originally called Wilson, Duggan, & Company), which was founded in 1854. Company production included the manufacture of all-purpose baking powder, other phosphates and special chemicals, patent medicines, and fertilizer. Horsford's development of baking powder was designated a National Historic Chemical Landmark in 2006.

Rumford Chemical Works was sold to Heyden Corporation in 1948 while the rights to baking powder were sold to a private owners under the name "Rumford Company." Essex Chemical Corporation purchased Rumford Chemical Works in 1956; while retaining headquarters in Rumford (East Providence), the company maintains offices around the world. The East Providence headquarters grounds were listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980.

This historical note was written with the help of the finding aids of "Records pertaining to the Apparatus of the Rumford Professorship and Lectureship on the Application of Science to the Useful Arts" (1835-1836, 1851) at Harvard University, in addition to the Horsford Family Papers (1681-1954) at the Rensselaer Institution Archives and Special Collections.

James Brown Herreshoff (1834 – 1930) was an American inventor and chemist. Herreshoff belongs to a notable American family of boat designers, chemists, and inventors. James Brown Herreshoff was born in Bristol, RI, and graduated from Brown University; he passed away died at the age of 96 in Riverdale, NY.

Wilson, Ray: Providence & Rumford, RI
Dates:
1889 August 12 & 27, November 8
Subsubseries d: American Civil War Army Rations
Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries d, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford's professional life in the form of communication with entrepreneurs, medical inspectors, physicians, and a variety of high-ranking officials from the U.S. Army and Navy during the American Civil War. Subsubseries d features seventy-six letters (183 pages) that document Horsford's unsuccessful trial manufacture of a chemically-enhanced ration of grain and meat designed to provide nutrition to troops. These contents trace the progression of Horsford's recipe with word from Albion Parris Howe, Amos Beebe Eaton, Colonel John Cunningham Kelton, Dr. Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden, General George Gordon Meade, General Marsena Rudolph Patrick, General Ulysses S. Grant, Lewis Henry Morgan, Lieutenant Colonel William B. Guernsey, Quartermaster General Montgomery Cunningham Meigs, Rear Admiral Charles Henry Davis, and Secretary of War, Edwin McMasters Stanton. In addition, this subsubseries includes a uniquely negative critique of Horsford's chemical creation from Union soldier "L.R. Williams," who served in the 5th Regiment, Kansas Volunteer Calvary.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

1864 July 21

4 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 7.5"

Davis, Rear Admiral Charles Henry with Others: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1863 July 10; 1864 July 27, August 1 & 21
Scope and Contents

4 Letters, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA," "Washington, D.C." ; "General William Raymond Lee, Boston, MA"

Sent From: "E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, The Abbey Manor [Sylvester Manor], Shelter Island," [NY] ; "Rear-Admiral, Chairman of the Permanent Commission, C.H. [Charles Henry] Davis, Bureau of Navigation, Navy Department, Washington, D.C." ; "William W.W. Wood, Chief Engineer, Office of General Insoector Steam Machinery & Company, U.S. Army, No. 256 Canal Street, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; National Academy of Sciences, Professor Bache, President; "the protection of ironclad ships"

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3.25" - 8" x 10"

Charles Henry Davis (January 16, 1807 – February 18, 1877) was a Rear Admiral in the U.S. Navy. Working for the Coast Survey, Davis researched tides and currents, and located an uncharted shoal that had caused wrecks off the New York coast. During the American Civil War, he commanded the Western Gunboat Flotilla, winning an important engagement in the Battle of Memphis, before capturing enemy supplies on a successful expedition up the Yazoo river. Davis' published works can be found at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Eaton, Amos Beebe: New York, NY; Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1865 February 18 & 20, March 15
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation & Notation

Addressed To: "Brigadier General Amos B. [Beebe] Eaton, Commissary General of Subsistence"

Sent From: [Eben Norton Horsford], "444 E Street," [Washington, D.C.]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

9 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 8" x 10"

Amos Beebe Eaton (May 12, 1806 – February 21, 1877) was a career officer in the U.S. Army, serving as a general for the Union during the American Civil War. Eaton archival material can be found at the University of Miami, Otto G. Richter Library in Coral Gables, FL and Yale University in New Haven, CT.

Grant, General Ulysses S: City Point, VA
Dates:
1865 July 15
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: "Honorable E.M. [Edwin McMasters] Stanton, Secretary of War"

Sent From: "General U.S. [Ulysses S.] Grant, Head Quarters, Army of the Potomac, Office of the Provost Marshall General / City Point, VA," [likely dictated & written by his secretary's hand]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford's ration proposal

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Ulysses S. Grant (born Hiram Ulysses Grant; April 27, 1822 – July 23, 1885) was the 18th President of the United States (1869–1877). As Commanding General, Grant worked closely with President Abraham Lincoln to lead the Union Army to victory over the Confederacy in the American Civil War. Grant implemented Congressional Reconstruction, often at odds with Lincoln's successor, Andrew Johnson. Twice elected president, Grant led the Republicans in their effort to remove the vestiges of Confederate nationalism and slavery, protect African-American citizenship, and support economic prosperity nationwide. The Ulysses S. Grant Papers (1844-1922) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Guernsey, Lieutenant Colonel William B: Beaufort, SC
Dates:
1865 January 13
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "W.B. [William B.] Guernsey, Lieutenant Colonel, 26th [Regiment], U.S.C. [United States Colored] Troops, Camp Fort Duane, Near Beaufort, SC"

In Reference To: All-Black Regiment / African American Soldiers / American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science / U.S.C.T. [United States Colored Troops]

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Lieutenant Colonel William B. Guernsey led the 26th Regiment United States Colored Troops / New York Infantry between June 18 - August 28, 1865. The 26th Regiment was an African American combat unit, one of three "colored troop" units from New York that fought during the American Civil War.

Hayden, Dr. Ferdinand Vandeveer: Washington, DC; Winchester, VA
Dates:
1864 December 21 - 1865 November 1
Scope and Contents

6 Letters, 1 Envelope with Postage & Seal

Addressed To: "[Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Commissioner J. Mason, U.S. Patent Office, Washington, D.C." ; "[Dr.] F.V. [Ferdinand Vandeveer] Hayden, Office of the Chief Medical Officer, Winchester, VA"

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Dr. Edward Perry Vollum; General Sheridan; Lieutenant Colonel A.C. Hamlin; Nashville, TN; Trustees University of Pennsylvania; W. Hamlin

14 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8.25" x 3.75" - 5" x 8"

Dr. Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden (September 7, 1829 – December 22, 1887) was an American geologist noted for his pioneering surveying expeditions of the Rocky Mountains in the late 19th century. Hayden was also a physician who served with the Union Army during the American Civil War. Mike Foster's Strange Genius: The Life of Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden (1994), in addition to Hayden's published works are available in New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Howe, Albion Parris: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1863 August 12
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "A.P. [Albion Parris] Howe"

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Albion Parris Howe (March 13, 1818 – January 25, 1897) was a Union Army general during the American Civil War. Howe's contentious relationships with superior officers in the Army of the Potomac eventually led to his being deprived of division command.

Jenkins, J. Foster: New York, NY
Dates:
1864 September 6 & 12

Kelton, Colonel John Cunningham: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1864 April 27
Scope and Contents

1 Letter Draft

Addressed To: "Colonel [John Cunningham] Kelton"

Sent From: "[Eben Norton] Horsford"

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 12.75"

Colonel John Cunningham Kelton (June 24, 1828 – July 15, 1893) was a U.S. Army officer; he served as the Adjutant General of the U.S. Army from 1889 to 1892. Kelton was appointed to the 6th Infantry, in which he served until the outbreak of the American Civil War; he served in various staff positions during the war including the rank Colonel of Volunteers. Kelton correspondence can be found in the Cutts-Madison Papers (1759-1912) at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.

Macy, CR: New York, NY
Dates:
1864 September 10; October 29; November 23
Scope and Contents

3 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "C.R. Macy, 36 [Harsen Street], New York," [NY]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Financial / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Alex E. Hasack, MD; Farina Cocido; Fordyce Barker, MD, Professor in Bellevue Hospital Medical College; John C. Hutchinson, MD, Professor of Surgery, College Hospital, Long Island, [NY]; John H. Griscom, MD

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 7.75" x 9.75"

Marshall, WC: New York, NY
Dates:
1864 May 11
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "[Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq."

Sent From: "W.C. Marshall, Provisions, No. 10, 12, & 14 Second Avenue, New York," [NY]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

3 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Meade, General George Gordon: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1865 December 14
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Indentation & Notation

Addressed To: "General [Ulysses S.] Grant"

Sent From: "General George [Gordon] Meade, Headquarters, Army of the Potomac," [Washington, D.C.]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Professor Eben Norton Horsford of Cambridge, MA, Army Ration Proposal; "Secretary of War Endorsement"

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 3" - 4.75" x 7.5"

George Gordon Meade (December 31, 1815 – November 6, 1872) was a career U.S. Army officer and civil engineer involved in the coastal construction of several lighthouses. Meade fought with distinction in the Second Seminole War and the Mexican-American War. During the American Civil War, Meade served as a Union general, rising from command of a brigade to the Army of the Potomac. Meade is best known for defeating Confederate General Robert E. Lee at the Battle of Gettysburg in 1863. The George Gordon Meade Collection (1811-1897) is preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, PA.

Meigs, Montgomery Cunningham: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1865 August 23
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "[Eben Norton] Horsford, Esq., Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "MC [Montgomery Cunningham] Meigs, Quartermaster General's Office, Washington, D.C."

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

2 Pages, Bound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Montgomery Cunningham Meigs (May 3, 1816 – January 2, 1892) was a career U.S. Army officer, civil engineer, construction engineer for a number of facilities in Washington, D.C., and Quartermaster General of the U.S. Army during and after the American Civil War. The Montgomery Cunningham Meigs Papers (1816-1892) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Mitchell, [Con. S.]: New York, NY
Dates:
1864 July 1
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "[Con. S.] Mitchell, Secretary of [Board of Officers], New York," [NY], [Possibly NY Councilman / Congressman / Political Official]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 7.75" x 9.75"

Morgan, Lewis Henry: Rochester, NY
Dates:
1864 July 21; 1865 March 14
Scope and Contents

2 Letters with Indentation

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "L.H. [Lewis Henry] Morgan"

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Hamlin & Hayden; Lansing, MI

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Lewis Henry Morgan (November 21, 1818 – December 17, 1881) was a pioneering American anthropologist, lawyer, and social theorist. Morgan is best known for his work on kinship and social structure, his theories of social evolution, and his ethnography of the Iroquois. Morgan entered the U.S. Army by the intervention of his friend, Ulysses S. Grant, and served on Grant's staff during the American Civil War. The Lewis Henry Morgan Papers (1826-1996) are preserved at the River Campus Library, University of Rochester in Rochester, NY.

Patrick, Marsena Rudolph: Geneva, NY
Dates:
1865 September 8
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford"

Sent From: "M.R. [Marsena Rudolph] Patrick"

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; General Gould of Rochester; General Terry, Department of Virginia

3 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Marsena Rudolph Patrick (March 15, 1811 – July 27, 1888) was a college president and U.S. Army officer, serving as a general in the Union volunteer forces during the American Civil War. Patrick was the provost marshal for the Army of the Potomac in many of its campaigns. Inside Lincoln's Army; The Diary of Marsena Rudolph Patrick, Provost Marshal General, Army of the Potomac is available at the New York Historical Society in New York, NY.

Stanton, Edwin McMasters: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1857 July 8; 1864 April 25; 1865 February 18 & 20
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 Letter Drafts with Notation

Addressed To: "Honorable Edwin M. [McMasters] Stanton, Secretary of War," [Washington, D.C.]; [Eben Norton Horsford]

Sent From: [Eben Norton Horsford], "Cambridge, MA" ; "Edwin M. [McMasters] Stanton, Secretary of War, War Department," [Washington, D.C.]

In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; "Case of Concentrated Ration" ; General Ulysses S. Grant's Recommendation

19 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5" x 8" - 8" x 12.5"

Edwin McMasters Stanton (December 19, 1814 – December 24, 1869) was an American lawyer and politician who served as Secretary of War under the Abraham Lincoln Administration during most of the American Civil War. Stanton archival material can be found at the Indiana Historical Society in Indianapolis, IN, the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., and the New York Historical Society in New York, NY.

Series B: Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series B, pertains to Mary L'Hommedieu Horsford's personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by genre. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of invitations and letters. Series 2: Manuscripts and Printed Materials consists of private and professional documentation in the form of diary entries, collected and original poetry by Mary and others, records of Mary's writing process in the form of manuscripts, printing proofs, and typescripts of her work Indian Legends and Other Poems. Series 2 also includes ephemera and printed materials in the form of a personal bible full of marginalia; Jared Bell Waterbury's Advice to a Young Christian on the Importance of Aiming at an Elevated Standard of Piety (1830) was once a part of this series, but it has been removed to the Fales Special Collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate this work.

Biographical Note

Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford was born on September 26, 1824 to Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine Gardiner. Mary was privately tutored on Shelter Island before attending the Albany Female Academy, where she met Eben Norton Horsford. Mary and Eben wed in 1847 and later produced four daughters: "Lilian" (Mary Leila Horsford Farlow), "Kate" (Mary Katherine Horsford), Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske, and "Mamie" (Mary Gardiner Horsford Curtis). Mary was a poet and had several works published in local newspapers; her volume Indian Legends and Other Works was published in 1855. Mary passed away on November 25, 1855, only months after Mamie was born.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series B, Subseries 1, pertains to Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford's personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and members of her local community. Genres range from contact in the form of invitations, letters, and collected and original poetry.

Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Mary's personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, private family business and Shelter Island estate management, to public and shared social experiences, testimonies of religious faith, to travel. This subseries features seventy-seven letters (281 pages) from "A.D.W." or "Cousin Abby," (possibly Abby Dwight Woodbridge), in which Abby shares her love of poetry with Mary.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Series C: Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series C, pertains to Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford's personal and public life in the form of three series arranged by record type. Subseries 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of invitations, letters, and telegrams. Subseries 2: Financial and Legal consists of account books, appraisals, home and life insurance documentation, inventories, tax records, and three drafts of Phoebe's will. Subseries 3: Notebooks and Printed Materials features private papers in the form ephemera, manuscripts, and notation, with collected and original poetry and genealogical writing.

Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by company or individual surname, while the materials of Subseries 2 and Subseries 3 are arranged alphabetically by record type[s] and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Biographical Note

Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford was born on August 13, 1826 to Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner. With sister Mary Gardiner Horsford, Phoebe was privately tutored until she attended Albany Female Academy and met Eben Norton Horsford. Phoebe was an accomplished seamstress and married Eben Norton Horsford on July 22, 1857, after his first wife, her sister Mary, passed away just two years earlier. Eben and Phoebe produced one daughter, "Nellie" (Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford). Phoebe passed away October 8, 1900 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series C, Subseries 1, pertains to Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford's personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and an assortment of aristocracy. Genres range from contact in the form of announcements, calling / visiting cards, financial records in the form of bills, checks, and receipts, invitations, illustrations, letters, notation, manuscripts of travel writing, ornate lace valentines featuring bird, floral, and hair designs, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, and telegrams; and original and reproductions of printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, newsprint clippings, and pamphlets.

Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Phoebe's personal life, featuring over 361 letters (2,065 pages) just from her immediate family. Subjects range from current community events, local and international travel, to private family business and Shelter Island estate management, public and shared social experiences, to testimonies of religious faith. This subseries features communication with the New England elite of the period including Anne Charlotte Lynch Botta, Caroline Lane Jebb, Edith Longfellow Dana and Richard Henry Dana III, Elizabeth Aspinwall Pulsifer Wyman and Morrill Wyman, Frederick Albion Ober, Helen Hunt Jackson, Henry James, Sr., Henry Van Brunt, James Russell Lowell, Julia Gardiner Tyler, Sara Chapman Thorp Bull, and Sarah Orne Jewett. In addition, these contents include genealogical information from Fannie Washington Finch (Frances Louisa Augustus Washington Finch), great-great niece of the first president of the United States, George Washington.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

subject
Portrait Prints, British.; Family |x Religious life.

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional; Advertisement for interest rates

2 Pages, Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 3"

Arnold, Newton Darling (ND): Providence, RI
Dates:
1896 November 21 - 1898 December 20
Scope and Contents

6 Letters, 6 Envelopes with Postage, 1 Calling / Visiting Card

Addressed To: "Mr. [N.D. / Newton Darling] Arnold," "Phoebe [Dayton Gardiner] Horsford, 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Mrs. Eben Norton Horsford," "N.D. [Newton Darling] Arnold"

In Reference To: Business / Friendship / Personal / Professional / Social; 2 printed copies of correspondence referring to Rumford Chemical Works Thanksgiving & Christmas celebrations for employees

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Byerly, WE: Philadelphia, PA; Southwest Harbor, ME
Dates:
1884 July 24 & August 8
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: "Mrs. [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "W.E. Byerly, 871 Holly Street West, Philadelphia, PA," "Stanley House, Southwest Harbor, ME"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Boston, MA; Newport, RI

9 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 3" - 5" x 8"

W.E. Byerly (December 13 1849 - 1935) was an American mathematician who earned his Ph.D. in 1873, the first in mathematics at Harvard University, with a thesis entitled "The Heat of the Sun." Byerly taught at Cornell University (1873 - 1876) and at Harvard until his retirement.

Dates:
1884 August 19; 1891 August 13

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel

14 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 3.75" x 2.75" - 5" x 8"

Dana III, Richard Henry: Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA
Dates:
1891 August 1
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Mrs. [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Richard H. [Henry] Dana, [III]," [Husband of Edith Longfellow Dana]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Andrew Fiske & Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske; Mr. & Mrs. Wheeler

4 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 3" - 4" x 6"

Richard Henry Dana III (January 3, 1851 - December 16, 1931) was an American lawyer, civil service reformer, and Harvard graduate. Dana was the son of Richard Henry Dana Jr., and Harvard graduate; he married in 1878 to Edith Longfellow (1853 – 1915), the daughter of poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. Family archival materials can be found at Harvard (the Houghton Library and the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study), the Massachusetts Historical Society, the Middlebury College Library (Abernathy Collections), and the Longfellow House at Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site.

Dates:
1884 July 23

Addressed To: "Mrs. [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], Shelter Island, Long Island, NY"

Benjamin Ives Gilman (1852 – 1933) was the Secretary of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts from 1893 to 1925. Gilman's published works can be found at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5" x 8"

James, Henry: London, England
Dates:
undated, circa 1880s
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: [Mr. / Mrs. Horsford] [Eben Norton Horsford or Phoebe Dayton Gardiner]

Sent From: "Henry James," [Possibly Henry James Sr., or Henry James, Jr.]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social

2 Pages, Bound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 6"

Henry James, Sr. (June 3, 1811 in Albany, New York – December 18, 1882 in Boston, Massachusetts) was an American theologian and adherent of Swedenborgianism. James is known as the father of the philosopher William James, novelist Henry James, and diarist Alice James. The James Family Papers are preserved at The Center For Henry James Studies at Creighton University in Omaha, NE.

Jebb, Caroline Lane: Erie & Philadelphia, PA
Dates:
1884 August 6 & September 1
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: "Mrs. [Eben Norton] Horsford / Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Caroline L. [Lane] Jebb, 4102 Spruse Street, Philadelphia, PA," "℅ Major J.W. Reynolds, Erie, PA / Springfield, Newnham, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Mr. White; New London, CT; New York, Yale College

10 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 3" - 5" x 8"

Caroline Lane Jebb Lady Jebb, née Reynolds then Slemmer, (1840 - July 11, 1930), was an American intellectual and socialite. Jebb's biography and selected correspondence were published in 1960 by Mary Reed Bobbitt, whose papers are preserved by the Five College Consortium.

Kearsie, Anne: Denmark; England; Massachusetts
Dates:
1883 July 31 & August 17; 1884 July 20; 1886 August 19

Lane, George Martin: Cambridge, MA; Cologne, Germany; London, England
Dates:
1886 July 3; 1893 January 1; 1897 January 2; [no year] October 21 & undated, circa 1890 - 1897
Scope and Contents

5 Letters, 3 Envelopes with Notation & Postage, 2 Calling / Visiting Cards with Notation

Addressed To: "Mr. Lane" ; "Mrs. [Eben Norton] Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA / Shelter Island, NY," "Fifth Avenue Hotel, New York, NY"

Sent From: "George M. [Martin] Lane, 8 Mercer Circle, Brattle Street," [Cambridge, MA], "31 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA," "℅ [M. James], Brown, Shipley & Company, London, [England], Cologne," [Germany], [Husband to Frances Eliza Gardiner Lane, Father to Gardiner Martin Lane, Brother-In-Law to Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford] ; "Phoebe G. Horsford"

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Wellesley Ceremonial

26 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 3" x 1.5" - 5" x 8"

George Martin Lane (1823 - 1897) was an American educator and scholar. Lane's association with Harvard was life-long: he was a Cambridge native, attended Harvard as an undergraduate, and taught at Harvard for 43 years. The George Martin Lane Papers are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA.

Stoughton, Mary Fiske: Cambridge & Nonquitt, MA
Dates:
1886
Scope and Contents

3 Letters, 3 Envelopes with Postage, 1 Western Union Telegraph Form

Addressed To: "Professor Eben [Norton] Horsford, For Mrs. Horsford, [Phoebe Dayton Gardiner], Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Mary Fiske Stougton, 90 Brattle Street, Cambridge, MA," "Nonquitt via New Bedford," [Nonquitt Dartmouth, MA]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social

13 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 3.75" - 8" x 5.25"

The Mary Fiske Stoughton House is a National Historic Landmark house at 90 Brattle Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Henry Hobson Richardson designed the house in 1882 in what is now called the "Shingle Style," with a minimum of ornament and shingles stretching over the building's irregular volumes like a skin. The house drew immediate notice in the architectural community, and was a significant influence in the growth in popularity of the Shingle style in the late 19th century. Richardson's masterful use of space in its design also foreshadowed the work of major 20th century architects, including Frank Lloyd Wright. The house was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1989.

Series D: Mary Leila Horsford Farlow (Lilian)

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series D, pertains to Mary Leila Horsford Farlow's personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by record type. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of letters, greeting cards, photographs, postcards, and printed ephemera. Series 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials consists of private and professional documentation in the form of a booklet, collected and original artwork and poetry, financial records in the form of account books, notation, and receipts, juvenilia, and manuscripts and notebooks of collected research.

Biographical Note

"Lilian," (Mary Leila Horsford Farlow, September 18, 1848 - August 16, 1927) was the eldest daughter of Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Lilian travelled often with her father, accompanying him to Europe in 1873 and 1880, and on a trip to the western United States in 1880 - 1881. Lilian was affiliated with both Radcliffe and Wellesley Colleges, and active in campaigning for educational opportunities for women. Lilian resided in the Horsford family home in Cambridge, MA, until her marriage to Dr. William Gilson Farlow on December 10, 1900.

William Gilson Farlow (December 17, 1844 - June 3, 1919) was an American botanist. Born in Boston, MA, and educated at Harvard (A.B. 1866; M.D. 1870), and after several years of European study, Farlow became an adjunct professor of botany in 1874 and professor of cryptogamic botany in 1879. Farlow corresponded with Caroline Bingham and Jacob Georg Agardh to collaborate in the identification and classification of species of algae previously unknown to science. In 1899, Farlow became the president of the American Society of Naturalists; in 1904, president of the National Academy of Sciences; in 1905, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science; and in 1911, president of the Botanical Society of America. Farlow received honorary degrees from Harvard University, the University of Glasgow (LL.D 1901), and the University of Wisconsin–Madison.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series D, Subseries 1, pertains to Lilian's personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and local professionals. Record types range from contact in the form of announcements, greeting cards, invitations, illustrations, letters, notation, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, and receipts; and printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, and pamphlets.

Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Lilian's personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, genealogical and history inquiries, private family business and Shelter Island estate management, public and shared social experiences, to local and international travel. This subseries features twenty-six letters (129 pages) from Lilian's sister Kate, Mary Katherine Horsford, while Lilian visited both Gardiners Island and Shelter Island, and while Kate traveled throughout the American midwest and northeast.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Agassiz, Elizabeth Cabot Cary: Nahant, MA
Dates:
1885 September 12 & 15
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss [Mary Leila] Lilian Horsford [Farlow], ℅ Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford, Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island," [MA]

Sent From: "E.C. [Elizabeth Cabot Cary] Agassiz, Quincy Street, Cambridge, [MA] / Nahant, MA"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Mr. Gilman

10 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 3.75" - 4.5" x 7"

Elizabeth Cabot Agassiz (née Cary) (December 5, 1822 – June 27, 1907) was an American educator, and the co-founder and first president of Radcliffe College. As a researcher of natural history, she was a contributing author to many scientific published works with her husband, Louis Agassiz. The Elizabeth Cabot Cary Agassiz Papers (1822-1907) are preserved at the Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe College Archives, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA.

Prime, Nina: Bar Harbor, ME
Dates:
1886 September 17

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss Lilian [Mary Leila] Horsford [Farlow], Shelter Island, Suffolk County, NY" Sent From: "Nina Prime, Bar Harbor, ME," [Sister of Temple Prime]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel

5 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 3.75" - 4.5" x 7"

Prime, Temple: Huntington, NY
Dates:
1886 September 14
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss [Mary Leila Lilian] Horsford [Farlow], Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, Suffolk County, NY"

Sent From: "Temple Prime, Huntington, Suffolk County, NY," [Brother of Nina Prime]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Sister Nina Prime in Bar Harbor, ME

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.5" x 3" - 5" x 8"

Temple Prime (September 14, 1832 – February 25, 1903) was an amateur conchologist. Prime studied under Louis Agassiz at Harvard University and described several new species of the bivalve family Cycladidae. Prime's works can be found at New York University Library via Bobcat.

Reeve & Bartlett: Greenport, NY

Tyler, David Gardiner: Sherwood Forest, VA
Dates:
1886 May 10
Scope and Contents

1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss Lilian [Mary Leila] Horsford [Farlow], ℅ Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "D. [David] Gardiner Tyler, P.O. Sturgeon Point, James River, Sherwood Forest," [VA], [Cousin of Mary Leila Horsford Farlow]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social

6 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 3" - 5" x 8"

David Gardiner Tyler (July 12, 1846 – September 5, 1927), was a lawyer, judge, and United States Democratic Party politician. David was the first child of John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States and his second wife Julia Gardiner Tyler; he dropped out of present-day Washington and Lee University to fight in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War. The Tyler Family Papers (1716-1946) are preserved at the Earl Gregg Swem Library at The College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA.

Dates:
1886 June 3

25 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Measurements: 4.5" x 3.5" - 8.5" x 11"

Subseries 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series D, Subseries 2, consists of Lilian's private papers including artwork in the form of pencil illustrations and a watercolor painting, financial records in the form of an account book, notes and receipts, juvenila in the form of paper dolls and pressed plants, and personal writing. Lilian's journal, manuscripts, and notebooks are full of genealogical and historical research, inventories, recipes, and poetry. Although Series D, Subseries 2 is dominated by personal documentation, these contents also include an account book detailing estate management for the Harlow and Gardiner property on Shelter Island between 1893 - 1918, tax receipts for the Union Free School District No. 1 on Shelter Island from 1915, and a handwritten reissue of a Rumford Chemical Works Patent from 1921.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by record type[s] and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

1894

Dates:
1903; 1921 June 18

Series E: Mary Katherine Horsford (Kate)

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series E, pertains to Mary Katherine Horsford's personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by record type. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of accessories (bracelets), letters, greeting cards, photographs, postcards, printed ephemera, telegrams, and visiting cards. Series 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials consists of private papers in the form of a financial record, a sketchbook, a selection of travel writing, bound research and visitor lists, and original poetry.

Biographical Note

Mary Katherine Horsford (1850 - 1927), "Kate" was the second daughter of Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Born in Cambridge, MA, Kate was fond of writing poetry, sketching, and watercolor painting; she also accompanied her father to Europe during his trip to the Vienna Exposition in 1873. Kate never wed and lived at Sylvester Manor with her sister Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford, where she contributed to the ground's garden development.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series E, Subseries 1, pertains Kate's personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and local and international professionals. Genres range from contact in the form of accessories (bracelets), greeting cards, engravings, invitations, letters, notation, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, telegrams, and visiting cards; and ephemera in the form of advertisements, flyers, and pamphlets.

Series E, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Kate's personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, genealogical and history inquiries, private family business, public and shared social experiences, to local and international travel. This subseries features eleven letters from American chemist Charles Avery Doremus (September 6, 1851 - December 2, 1925) while he was completing his PhD at the universities of Leipzig and Heidelberg in Germany between 1870 - 1873. The son of chemist and physician Robert Ogden Doremus, Charlie became a toxicology expert and a holder of patents for a process of softening water, a gas furnace, producing hydrofluoric acid, extracting alumina from clay, and extracting potash from feldspar.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 3" x 3" - 5" x 8"

Subseries 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series E, Subseries 2 consists of Mary Katherine Horsford, "Kate's" private papers in the form of a financial record, a sketchbook, a selection of travel writing, research, visitor lists, and original poetry.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by record type and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Series F: Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series F pertains to Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske's personal life in the form of letters from her friends and sisters.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Biographical Note

Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske (1852 - 1920) was born to Eben Norton Horsford and Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford in Cambridge, MA. Gertrude married Boston attorney Andrew Fiske (1854 - 1897) in 1878, and they produced five children: Impressionist figure and landscape painter Gertrude Horsford Fiske (1879 - 1961), Dr. Augustus Henry Fiske (born 1880), Eben Norton Fiske (born 1883), Gardiner Horsford Fiske (born 1892), and Cornelia Horsford Fiske (Mrs. Harold Willis) (born 1895).

Series G: Mary Gardiner Horsford Curtis (Mamie)

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series G pertains to Mamie's personal life in the form of letters from her friends and sisters.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Biographical Note

Mary Gardiner Horsford Curtis (August 27, 1855 - 1893) "Mamie" was the youngest daughter of Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner and Eben Norton Horsford. Mamie married the son of a U.S. Supreme Court Justice & Rhode Island attorney and judge, Benjamin Robbins Curtis (June 8, 1855 - January 21, 1891) in 1877. Mamie and Benjamin produced one daughter: Mary Gardiner Curtis (July 5, 1879 - May 11, 1961).

Series H: Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford (Nellie)

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series H pertains to Nellie's personal and professional life in which it includes correspondence, clippings and ephemera, genealogical and local history research, financial and legal records, notebooks, photographs, printed works, original and collected artwork and poetry, and Sylvester Manor blueprints and inventories for the 1908 renovation.

Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.

Biographical Note

"Nellie" (Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford, September 25, 1861 - 1944) was the only daughter of Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Cornelia was an amateur watercolor painter, a poet, and travelled extensively; family trips around the North American west and Europe influenced her interest in archaeology, gardening, and history. While continuing Eben Norton Horsford's Northmen and Norumbega work, Cornelia sponsored an expedition to Iceland to compare structures built by Viking settlers to those in Massachusetts. Cornelia also conducted Sylvester family genealogical and Shelter Island local history research. After Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford passed away in 1900, Cornelia managed Sylvester Manor and oversaw a substantial renovation in 1908.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series H, Subseries 1, consists of Nellie's personal and professional correspondence, but also includes financial records, legal records, and research. Genres range from communication in the form of greeting cards, invitations, letters, notation, original and collected artwork and poetry, photographs, postcards, telegrams, and visiting cards; ephemera in the form of flyers, pamphlets, pressed plants, a recreational sport booklet, and newsprint clippings; financial records in the form of insurance and stock account notation; and legal records in the form of employee and property contracts, inventories, and wills.

Series H, Subseries 1, is dominated by items that capture Cornelia's personal life through communication with family and friends. Subjects range from local current events, obituaries, travel, and weddings, to contact with her nephews Lieutenant Gardiner Horsford Fiske and Gouverneur Morris Phelps while they were both serving in the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. Series H, Subseries 1 preserves Cornelia's professional life in the form of research; subjects range from gardening, genealogy, to local history and Sylvester Manor estate management, in which Cornelia conducts conversations with academics, businessmen, librarians, legal and real estate professionals, and government workers. This subseries also includes prints of twenty-four United States patents assigned by Dr. Augustus Henry Fiske while he was chief chemist at Rumford Chemical Works. See related records in Record Group V: Fiske Family, Series A: Correspondence and Research, Box 117, Folder 41, for Andrew Fiske's collection of his father's patents.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

7 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 6.5"

Fiske, Gardiner Horsford: [Unidentified Location, U.S. Air Force]
Dates:
1918 March 27 & 28; undated, circa 1918
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 1 Envelope with Postage

Addressed To: "Dear Aunt Cornelia," "Miss Cornelia [Conway Felton] Horsford, Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, NY"

Sent From: "Lieutenant [Gardiner Horsford] Fiske, U.S. Air Service, A.E.F. [American Expeditionary Forces]," [Nephew of Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Military / Personal / Social / Travel / WWI

7 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 3.25" - 4.75" x 6.25"

Gardiner Horsford Fiske enlisted as a flying cadet in Boston on April 30, 1917, and had training at Chandler Field, PA, before serving at Issoudon and Clermont-Ferrad, France during World War I. Fiske received his commission as 1st Lieutenant with the 20th Aero Squadron on January 27, 1918. One of Lt. Fiske's war adventures was when acting as an observer, he was thrown from his cockpit 2000 feet in the air, miraculously landed in front of the vertical stabilizer, and managed to crawl back into the aircraft. Fiske, then a Major, was an Intelligence Officer for the Eighth Air Force during World War II. Fiske's scrapbook is preserved at the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C.

Fiske, Gertrude: Cape Neddick & Ogunquit, ME; Waltham & Weston, MA
Dates:
1931 June 10; 1934 October 10 & 28; 1935 August 21
Scope and Contents

3 Postcards, 1 Letter, 1 Envelope with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: "Dearest Aunt Nini," "Miss Cornelia [Conway Felton] Horsford, Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island Heights, NY," "27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA"

Sent From: "Gertrude Fiske, Stadhaugh, Weston, MA" [Niece of Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford]

In Reference To: Family / Friendship / Personal / Social / Travel; Edith Green; Mrs. Wordberg; Willis Family

13 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink & Pencil

Measurements: 5.5" x 3.5" - 6" x 7"

Gatschet, Albert Samuel: Washington, D.C.
Dates:
1897 February 2 & 5
Scope and Contents

2 Letters, 2 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss [Cornelia Conway Felton] Horsford, 27 Craigie Street, Cambridge, MA; "[Mr. W. of McGee], Mr. Albert [Samuel] Gatschet"

Sent From: "Albert [Samuel] Gatschet, Smithsonian Institution, Bureau of American Ethnology, Washington, D.C." ; "Cornelia [Conway Felton] Horsford"

In Reference To: Academic / Education / Business / Professional; National Geographic Magazine, Norumbega

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 4.25" - 10.5" x 7.25"

Albert Samuel Gatschet (October 3, 1832, Beatenberg, Canton of Bern – March 16, 1907) was a Swiss-American ethnologist who trained as a linguist in the universities of Bern and Berlin, but later moved to the United States in order to study Native American languages, a field in which he was a pioneer. The Albert Samuel Gatschet Papers (1828-1906) are preserved in the National Anthropological Archives at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.

James, William: [Cambridge, MA]
Dates:
1888 May 2; 1889 January 8; [no year] January 18 & March 31, circa 1888
Scope and Content

4 Letters

Addressed To: "Miss Cornelia [Conway Felton] Horsford"

Sent From: "William James, 18 Garden Street," [Cambridge, MA]

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Shelter Island ghost story

9 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.75" x 7.75"

William James (January 11, 1842 – August 26, 1910) was an American philosopher and psychologist. Son of Henry James, Sr., and brother to diarist Alice James, and novelist Henry James, William was trained as a physician, and the first educator to offer a psychology course in the United States. Williams was one of the leading thinkers of the late 19th century and is often referred to as the "Father of American psychology." The William James Papers (1842-1910) are preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, in Cambridge, MA.

Series I: Assorted Horsford Materials

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series I: Assorted Horsford Materials contain documentation related to the Horsford family that belonged to multiple individuals or a case in which identification of a specific creator or owner could not be determined. Genres range from ephemera, gardening documentation, genealogical and local history research, newspapers and clippings, personal and professional correpsondence, poetry and personal manuscripts, Sylvester Manor financial papers, and a variety of printed materials such as clippings and newspapers.

Subseries 1: Correspondence

Scope and Contents

Record Group IV, Series I, Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.

Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.

Archery Club of Shelter Island
Dates:
undated, circa 1860 - 1890
Scope and Contents

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: "Miss Horsford" [Mary Leila (Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude Hubbard, Mary Gardiner (Mamie), Cornelia Conway Felton]

Sent From: The Archery Club of Shelter Island

In Reference To: Friendship / Leisure / Personal / Social / Sports

1 Page, Unbound

Handwritten in Pencil

Measurements: 4.5" x 7"

"Bachelor's German 1869"
Dates:
1869
Scope and Contents

1 Invitation with Envelope

Addressed To: "Miss Horsford" [Mary Leila (Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude Hubbard, Mary Gardiner (Mamie), Cornelia Conway Felton]

Sent From: "R.H.J. Goddard, W.G. Nightingale, L.T. Foster, W. Ames of the Committee"

3 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 8" x 10"

Daly, Maria [Lydig]: [Sag Harbor, NY]
Dates:
1884 July 17 & 19, September 18
Scope and Contents

3 Letters, 3 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: "Miss Horsford" [Mary Leila (Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude Hubbard, Mary Gardiner (Mamie), Cornelia Conway Felton]

Sent From: Maria [Lydig] Daly

In Reference To: Friendship / Leisure / Personal / Social; Entertaining, Sailing

8 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4" x 7"

Maria Lydig Daly (1824 - 1894) was an American Democrat, Dirarist, and Unionist. Maria is the author of Diary of a Union Lady, 1861-1865, was active in the Democratic Party, the Women's Central Association for the Relief for the Army, the New York Botanical Garden, and many other collectives during the American Civil War. Daly was the daughter of Philip Mesier Lydig (1739 - 1872), the last landholder of the property that became the Bronx Park and the New York Botanical Garden, and Katherine Suydam, eldest daughter of John Suydam, an early settler of New Netherland, also known as a "Knickerbocker." Maria married jurist, lecturer, and writer Charles Patrick Daly (1816 - 1899), who was a member of the New York State Assembly, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Common Pleas, and president of the American Geographical Society. The Charles Patrick Daly Papers (1829-1897) are preserved at the New York Public Library, Archives and Manuscripts Division, in New York, NY.

Dyer, Louis: Cambridge, MA
Dates:
1884 July 11
Scope and Contents

William Butler Ogden (1805 - 1877) was the first mayor of Chicago. The William Butler Ogden Papers (1829-1881) are preserved at the Chicago History Museum Research Center in Chicago, IL.

"ARP" : Cambridge, MA
Dates:
[no year] July 22, circa 1860 - 1890

Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "My dear Miss Horsford," [Mary Leila Farlow (Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude Hubbard, Mary Gardiner (Mamie), Cornelia Conway Felton (Nellie)]

Sent From: "J.M. Peirce"

In Reference To: Friendship / Personal / Social; Entertaining / Hospitality, Visiting Shelter Island

2 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5" x 8"

Preston, Henry Howard: Shelter Island, NY
Dates:
1889 March 13
Scope and Contents

1 Letter

Addressed To: "Miss Horsford," [Mary Leila Farlow (Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude Hubbard, Mary Gardiner (Mamie), Cornelia Conway Felton (Nellie)]

Sent From: "Henry Howard Preston - Real Estate, Insurance & Conveyance, Shelter Island, NY"

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Legal / Professional; Property Deed

2 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 5.25" x 8"

Henry Howard Preston served during the American Civil War, was the first salaried sheriff in Suffolk County (1903-1906), founded the Suffolk County Probation Department, and was a judge for the Court of Sessions.

Preston, Jesse [Smith]: Shelter Island, NY [1 of 3]
Dates:
1884 March - October
Scope and Contents

13 Letters, 8 Envelopes with Postage

Addressed To: [Eben Norton Horsford]; "Jesse Smith Preston, Sylvester Manor"

Sent From: [Cornelia Conway Felton (Nellie), Eben Norton, Mary Katherine (Kate), Mary Leila Farlow (Lilian), Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford]; "W.M. Ricker of W.M. Ricker & Son: Commission Dealers in Cattle, Sheep, Hogs, Butter, Eggs, Poultry & Company of Peacham, VT"

In Reference To: Business / Professional; Farming, Flowers, Sheep; Sylvester Manor Estate Management / Grounds Maintenance

45 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Printed & Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5" x 9"

Preston, Jesse [Smith]: Shelter Island, NY [2 of 3]
Dates:
1884 - 1886
Scope and Contents

12 Letters, 11 Envelopes with Notation & Postage

Addressed To: [Jesse Smith Preston, Sylvester Manor]

Sent From: "Eben Norton, Mary Katherine (Kate) & Mary Leila (Lilian) Horsford Farlow, Cambridge, MA"

In Reference To: Business / Professional; Sylvester Manor Estate Management / Grounds Maintenance

27 Pages, Bound & Unbound

Handwritten in Ink

Measurements: 4.5" x 7" - 5.5" x 9"

circa 1884-1889, 1925

Record Group V: Fiske Family

Scope and Contents

Record Group V: Fiske Family includes Sylvester Manor research conducted by Andrew and his wife Alice. Genres range from original and reproductions of ephemera, legal records, personal and professional correspondence, personal writing, and printed materials.

Biographical Note

Andrew Fiske (February 21, 1909 - August 31, 1992) was born in Cambridge, MA to Augustus Henry Fiske and Esther Bennett. Andrew was a thirteenth generation descendant of Nathaniel Sylvester and inherited Shelter Island upon the passing of his father in 1949. Andrew was a Harvard College and Business School graduate, and managed the Groton, CT Electric Boat Company during World War II. Fiske was the Long Island representative for Boston brokerage firm H.C. Wainwright, and was a founder, trustee and president of the Suffolk County Library. Fiske served for more than forty years on the Shelter Island Public Library board, and served for more than twenty years on the Shelter Island school board, the Eastern Long Island Hospital board, and with the Suffolk County Historical Society.

Alice Hench Fiske (November 9, 1917 - April 17, 2006) was born in Youngstown, OH to Laverne Willis Hench and Florence Ebersbach Hench. Alice graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1939 and married Andrew Fiske in 1952. Alice helped restore Sylvester Manor and its gardens to their 19th century glory. As the founder of the Andrew Fiske Memorial Center for Archaeological Research at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, she sponsored digs at Sylvester Manor. Alice was also a supporter of the Shelter Island Library, Shelter Island Historical Society, and the Shelter Island Garden Club.

Professional Correspondence

Dates:
1929 July 2

1 Letter with Notation

Addressed To: "Hugh C. Middleton, 228 Masonic Building, Augusta, GA"

Sent From: "Augustus [Henry] Fiske"
